{{Infobox sports season | title = 2019 Suncorp Super Netball season | league = [[Suncorp Super Netball]] | sport = [[Netball]] | logo = File:Suncorp-super-netball-logo.png | pixels = | caption = | duration = 27 April – 15 September 2019 | no_of_teams = 8 | attendance = | TV = [[Nine Network]] | top_pick = | picked_by = | season = Regular season | minor_premiers = | MVP = | MVP_link = | top_scorer = | top_scorer_link = | playoffs = | playoffs_link = | playoffs_MVP_link= | finals = Finals | finals_link = | finals_champ = | finals_runner-up = | finals_MVP = | finals_MVP_link = | seasonslist = | seasonslistnames = | prevseason_link = 2018 Suncorp Super Netball season | prevseason_year = 2018 | nextseason_link = 2020 Suncorp Super Netball season | nextseason_year = 2020 }} The '''2019 [[Suncorp Super Netball]] season''' will be the third season of the premier [[Netball in Australia|netball]] league in [[Australia]]. The season will begin on 27 April and conclude on 15 September 2019, however it will break for most of the month of July due to the [[2019 Netball World Cup|Netball World Cup]], which will be played in [[Liverpool]].{{cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/sport/netball/world-cup-break-for-super-netball-2019-competition-20181025-p50bwj.html|title=World Cup break for Super Netball 2019 competition|work=Fairfax Media|date=25 October 2018}} [[Sunshine Coast Lightning]] are the defending premiers.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-08-26/sunshine-coast-lightning-win-super-netball-grand-final/10166228|title=Lightning strikes twice as Sunshine Coast retain Super Netball title|work=ABC News|date=26 August 2018}} ==Overview== ===Teams=== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%;" |- ! [[HBF Stadium]] | |} ===Format=== The season is played over fourteen rounds, allowing every team to play each other twice, once at home and once away. The top four teams on the [[Standings|ladder]] at the conclusion of the [[Season (sports)#Regular_season|regular season]] qualify for the [[Playoffs|finals series]]. In the first week of the finals series, the 1st ranked team hosts the 2nd ranked team in the major semi-final (with the winner of that match to qualify for the [[Grand Final]]) and the 3rd ranked team hosts the 4th ranked team in the minor semi-final (with the loser of that match eliminated). The loser of the major semi-final then hosts the winner of the minor semi-final in the preliminary final. The winner of the major semi-final then hosts the winner of the preliminary final in the Grand Final. ==Player transfers== At the start of Super Netball in 2017, all players were contracted for a maximum of two years in line with the initial [[collective bargaining agreement]] negotiated by the players' association.{{cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/sport/netball/the-subplot-that-could-make-or-break-teams-heading-into-super-netball-finals-20180704-p4zpf0.html|title=The subplot that could make or break teams heading into Super Netball finals|work=Fairfax Media|date=4 July 2018}} Clubs were free to re-sign existing players in the last few weeks of the [[2018 Suncorp Super Netball season|2018 season]], before the transfer window opened for unimpeded acquisitions at the end of the season. Clubs were given until 25 September 2018 to finalise their rosters for the 2019 season.{{cite web|url=https://www.netballscoop.com/2018/08/its-head-hunting-season/|title=It's head hunting season|work=Netball Scoop|date=31 August 2018}} ===Arrivals=== The following table is a list of players who moved clubs/leagues into Super Netball, or were elevated into a permanent position in the senior team, during the off-season. [[File:AM012-09.jpg|thumb|Armenian stamp featuring the logo of the 38th Chess Olympiad (top)]] The '''38th [[Chess Olympiad]]''', organized by [[FIDE]] and comprising an openAlthough commonly referred to as the ''men's division'', this section is open to both male and female players. and a women's tournament, as well as several other events designed to promote the game of [[chess]], took place between 12–25 November 2008 in [[Dresden]], [[Germany]].[http://www.fide.com/calendar FIDE Calendar 2008]. fide.com There were 146 teams in the open event and 111 in the women's event. In total, 1277 players were registered. Both tournament sections were officiated by [[International Arbiter|international arbiter]] [[Ignatius Leong]] ([[Singapore]]). In a change from recent Olympiads, the number of rounds of the [[Swiss system tournament|Swiss system]] were reduced from 13 to 11 with [[accelerated pairings]]. For the first time, the women's division, like the open division, was played over four boards per round, with each team allowed one alternate for a total of five players. In another first, the final rankings were determined by match points, not game points. In the event of a draw, the tie-break was decided by 1. Deducted [[Sonneborn-Berger]]; 2. Deducted sum of match points; 3. Game points.[http://www.fide.com/fide/handbook.html?id=95&view=article FIDE Handbook] Retrieved on 2012-09-03. The [[time control]] for each game permitted each player 90 minutes their first 40 moves and 30 minutes for the rest of the game, with an additional 30 seconds increment for each player after each move, beginning with the first. As a new rule, no [[Draw by agreement|draws by agreement]] were permitted before 30 moves had been completed. Yet there were games drawn as soon as the 16th move, formally drawn by repetition against which there was no rule.[https://web.archive.org/web/20090131211339/http://schachlive.dresden2008.de/games/m/9/2/2/index.eng.html Dresden 2008]. dresden2008.de In addition, players who were not present at the board at the commencement of a round automatically forfeited the game. This rule was implemented to align chess with other sports events.[http://main.uschess.org/content/view/8893/141/ Let the Games Begin in Dresden] uschess.org, Mike Klein, 13 November 2008 ==Open event== [[File:Dresden Olympiad 2008.jpg|thumb|500px|Dresden Olympiad Scene]] The open division was contested by 146 teams representing 141 nations. Germany, as hosts, fielded three teams, whilst the ''[[International Braille Chess Association]]'' (IBCA), the ''International Physically Disabled Chess Association'' (IPCA), and the ''International Committee of Silent Chess'' (ICSC) each provided one squad. [[Morocco]] were signed up, but never appeared for their first round match and were disqualified. Defending champions [[Armenia]], once again led by [[Levon Aronian]], clinched their second consecutive title. Despite being seeded only eighth, they won nine out of eleven matches, drew against fourth-placed [[Ukraine]] and lost only (1½-2½) to runners-up [[Israel]], captained by [[Boris Gelfand]]. The Israelis finished one point behind Armenia. The [[United States]], led by [[Gata Kamsky]], took the bronze medals on a better tie break score than [[Vasyl Ivanchuk]] and the rest of the Ukrainian team after defeating Ukraine (3½-½) in the last round. Once again, the Russian team under captain [[Vladimir Kramnik]] were the pre-tournament favourites but finished disappointingly in fifth place. Kramnik, having recently lost a [[World Chess Championship 2008|world championship match]], performed well below his rating, as did the rest of the team, except alternate [[Dmitry Yakovenko]] who won the reserve board. [[File:AM011-09.jpg|thumb|The winning Armenian team]] Arguably the biggest surprise of the tournament was [[Vietnam]], who weren't even seeded in the top 30, but still managed to finish in ninth place, aided somewhat by the new tournament structure which allotted them some weaker opponents, although they did manage a 2-2 result against [[China]]. The German hosts finished 13th, while [[India]], without World Champion [[Viswanathan Anand]], had to settle for 16th place. :{| class="wikitable" |+ Open event results, #1–#10 ! # !! Country !! Accordingly, there was no overall prize, although Sargissian on the third board had the best performance of all players at the tournament: * Board 1: {{flagicon|HUN}} [[Peter Leko]] 2834 * Board 2: {{flagicon|ARM}} [[Vladimir Akopian]] 2813 * Board 3: {{flagicon|ARM}} [[Gabriel Sargissian]] 2869 * Board 4: {{flagicon|MNE}} [[Dragisa Blagojevic]] 2792 * Reserve: {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Dmitry Yakovenko]] 2794 ==Women's section== The women's division was contested by 111 teams representing 106 nations. Germany, as hosts, fielded three teams, whilst the ''[[International Braille Chess Association]]'' (IBCA), the ''International Physically Disabled Chess Association'' (IPCA), and the ''International Committee of Silent Chess'' (ICSC) each provided one squad. [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] won their fourth title, 12 years after the third one, narrowly defeating [[Ukraine]] on tie breaks. The two teams didn't meet during the tournament, but when the Ukrainians only drew their penultimate match against [[Serbia]] while the Georgians defeated former champions [[China]] (2½-1½), the gold was Georgia's to lose. In the last round they record a win (3-1) against the Serbian, who thus came to play a crucial role in the fight for the title, despite finishing in seventh place themselves. The Georgian team were led by former World Champion, 47-year-old [[Maia Chiburdanidze]], who delivered a stellar performance, winning the top board with the best performance of the tournament. The [[United States]] clinched the bronze medals on tie breaks, just ahead of [[Russia]] (with newly crowned World Champion [[Alexandra Kosteniuk]]) and [[Poland]]. The German hosts finished in 21st place. :{| class="wikitable" |+ Women's section results, #1–#10 ! # !! Country !! Players !! Average

{{flagcountry|AFG|2004}} || 1400 || 1 || || |} ===Individual medals=== For the first time, all board prizes were given out according to [[Performance rating (chess)|performance ratings]]. Accordingly, there was no overall prize, although reborn ex-champion Chiburdanidze on the top board had the best performance of all players at the tournament: * Board 1: {{flagicon|GEO}} [[Maia Chiburdanidze]] 2715 * Board 2: {{flagicon|USA}} [[Anna Zatonskih]] 2571 * Board 3: {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Nadezhda Kosintseva]] 2591 * Board 4: {{flagicon|POL}} [[Joanna Majdan-Gajewska|Joanna Majdan]] 2621 * Reserve: {{flagicon|UKR}} [[Natalia Zdebskaya]] 2528 ==Overall title== The [[Nona Gaprindashvili]] Trophy is awarded to the nation that has the highest total number of match points in the open and women's divisions combined. Where two or more teams are tied, they are ordered by the same tie breakers as in the two separate events. The trophy, named after the former women's World Champion (1961–78), was created by FIDE in 1997. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" |- ! # ! Team ! {{Other uses|Académica (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = Académica | nickname = | image = | fullname = Associação Académica do Mindelo | founded = April 1, 1940 | ground = Av 12 de Setembro
[[Estádio Municipal Aderito Sena]],
[[Mindelo]], [[Cape Verde]] | capacity = 5,000 | chairman = {{flagicon|Cape Verde}} Julio Wanhon | manager = | league = [[São Vicente Island League]] | season = [[2015–16 São Vicente Island League|2015-16]] | position =3rd | shirtsupplier =MOAVE | pattern_la1 = _thinwhiteborder | pattern_b1 = _nike_white | pattern_ra1 = _thinwhiteborder | pattern_sh1 = _nikewhite | pattern_so1 = _nikewhite | leftarm1 = 192552 | body1 = 192552 | rightarm1 = 192552 | shorts1 = 192552 | socks1 = 192552 | pattern_la2 = _thinblackborder | pattern_b2 = _aachen1112A | pattern_ra2 = _thinblackborder | pattern_sh2 = _nikeblack | pattern_so2 = _nikeblack | leftarm2 = FEFEFE | body2 = FEFEFE | rightarm2 = FEFEFE | shorts2 = FEFEFE | socks2 = FEFEFE | pattern_la3 = _redshoulders | pattern_b3 = _nike_2010_red | pattern_ra3 = _redshoulders | pattern_sh3 = _redsides | pattern_so3 = _color_2_stripes_red | leftarm3 = 989898 | body3 = 989898 | rightarm3 = 989898 | shorts3 = 989898 | socks3 = 989898 }} '''Associação Académica do Mindelo''' ([[Capeverdean Crioulo]], [[ALUPEC]] or [[ALUPEK]]: ''Akadémika'', [[São Vicente Crioulo language|São Vicente Crioulo]]: ''Académica'' or ''Akadémika'') is a [[Association football|football]] club that had played in the Premier division and the [[São Vicente Island League]] in [[Cape Verde]]. It is based in the city of [[Mindelo]] on the island of [[São Vicente, Cape Verde|São Vicente]] and plays in a stadium with a capacity of 5,000. The club is an affiliate of the Portuguese club [[Associação Académica de Coimbra – O.A.F.|Académica de Coimbra]]. It is one of the first teams ever to win a provincial title before independence, in 1953, a year later. There was no further competition until 1956. Académica won their first title since independence in 1989. Other titles includes four for the island including their recent 2006/07 season win and two opening tournaments along with their recent win. Académica Mindelo is one of the most successful football (soccer) clubs in Cape Verde and the island of São Vicente, having won about 18 [[List of football clubs in Cape Verde by honours won|official titles]], 4 are national and the remaining 14 are regional titles. There is an educational academy named Académica do Mindelo (Mindelo Academy) located in the city. The club has no relation to that academy. Today the main etymology is with the academy in the city. ==History== The club was founded on April 1, 1940, the first of the Académica affiliate in both Cape Verde and West Africa. Académica do Mindelo celebrated its 50th anniversary of the club's foundation in 1990 and later celebrated its 75th anniversary in 2015. ===Regional competitions=== Académica became the region's third club to have a title won in 1948, the club was had the third most until 1964, with the exception of 1961 to 1963 when it was second with [[GD Amarantes|Amarante]]. After winning their fourth title in 1964, they possess the second most number of titles in São Vicente, their last one was won in 2007 and was the last they appeared in the nationals, the title total became tied with [[FC Derby]] since 2014. With [[Alexandre Alhinho]] as coach in the late 1980s, it would be a successful year for the club, they won a title in 1987, in 1989, they were runner up in the regionals behind Mindelense. Later in the 2000s, the club had good players such as [[Carlos Lima]], [[Sténio]] and Kadú. Later on, Kadú chose to play with Mindelense. From 2007 to 2009, the best player in the club was [[Sténio]], a year later, he moved to the same club where Kadú went. In the Opening Tournament, Académica was the island's third club to possess a title done in 2002, from 2003, their rankings became second behind almighty Mindelense, Académica won their second and final title that became the Association Cup won in the 2006-07 season and was solely the second club to possess the most titles. In 2010, their titles became shared with Derby and Académica's totals is now third behind Derby. Académica do Mindelo participated in the 2007 regional super cup played in 2008 and claimed their only title after defeating FC Derby, their title totals was also shared with that club and from 2010 Batuque. Académica as cup winner came back to challenge the champion Batuque in the 2010 super cup played in 2011, it was the club's second and final appearance and lost the title to that club. Académica's super cup title total became third with Derby behind Batuque, their title total was shared with Falcões do Norte from 2013, from 2017, the club's single title total became fourth and last alongside Falcões. Académica Mindelo was relegated once in the early to mid 2010s to the Second Division, the club returned to the Premier Division in the 2014–15 season after being in the top two positions. The sponsor for the 2014–15 season was MOAVE.{{cite web|url=http://www.criolosports.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5962:futebol-sao-vicente-moave-patrocina-academica-do-mindelo-para-epoca-20142015&catid=32:futebol-sao-vicente&Itemid=74|title=Futebol São Vicente: MOAVE patrocina Académica do Mindelo para época 2014/2015|trans-title=''MOAVE, Académica's sponsor for the 2014–15 season''|publisher=Criolosport|date=17 December 2014|accessdate=19 December 2014}} {{pt icon}} Also in the season, the club celebrated its 75th anniversary on April 1. Académica finished 7th which brought them to their promotional match that the club won six in the first match over [[Castilho (Mindelo)|Castilho]], the second match was tied at three, with a total of nine goals, Académica was kept in the Premier Division. Académica participate in the 2016 Association Cup, the club finished sixth in the Pemier Division with 7 points and two wins, the club scored 7 goals alongside [[SC Farense de Fonte Filipe|Farense]] which was second in the Premier Division. In the same time, Académica's title totals is now shared with Batuque's. The 2016-17 season had a good start and up to the middle of the week had their positions above Mindelense. In the first part of the season, [[Carlos Lima|Calú]] was with the club. The club was thought to be first place up to the 13th round (originally with 29 points), in April, Derby made a protest that the club was using a goalkeeper with a fake identity. On April 24, the Disciplinary Council of the [[Cape Verdean Football Federation]], removed every points that the fake goalkeeper had played totalling 11 and included one with Salamansa, Derby, Farense, the almighty Mindelense and Ribeira Bote, from February 25, they were the first three matches and the last two matches on April 15.{{cite web|url=http://www.criolosports.com/index.php/futebol-sao-vicente/2477-futebol-regional-sao-vicente-academica-do-mindelo-perde-titulo-na-secretaria|title=Futebol regional São Vicente:Académica do Mindelo perde título na secretaria|trans-title=São Vicente Regional: Académica do Mindelo Lost the Title by the Secretary|newspaper=Criolosport|language=pt|date=25 April 2017|accessdate=13 May 2017}} Their positions were dropped from first to fifth and also, their National qualification was lost.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}, all this will remove the coach from the club and formed the club's part of some match fixing. The second place position was replaced by FC Derby, earlier positions were also changed, the club was actually third, then fifth and their points was 18. But they did well on an April 1 match over Falcões do Norte as no fake goalkeeper took part.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} After that, Académica's final match of the season was a win over Derby 0-2 and finished third with 21 points and had 7 wins and losses behind [[CS Mindelense]] and [[FC Derby]], Farense took the fifth position and fourth was [[Batuque FC|Batuque]]. Académica Mindelo started the regional season with the association cup, Académica Mindelo lost the first round match and Académica Mindelo is in the mid position at the sixth round already unable to win another title. Académica finished fourth place, better than last season, they also had 10 points, three wins, a win more than last season, and a draw the same, yet again scored seven goals, sixth and last in the Premier Division, shared with [[SC Ribeira Bote|Ribeira Bote]]. Académica Mindelo started the 2017-18 regional Premier Division championships in the second week of December with a victory over Ribeira Bote, up next were fourth straight losses, first to the almighty [[CS Mindelense|Mindelense]], then [[GS Castilho|Castilho]], then the non-powerful [[Salamansa FC|Salamansa]] and recently Batuque, currently the club is sixth place. During the break in the Premier Division on January 20, 2018, the regional cup begun, it seemed they were successful in that competition as they defeated Ribeira Bote in penalties after the match ended without any goals scored. Académica continued their worst, a very minimal relief the club made with two consecutive draws with three goals each in rounds 7 and 8. Académica lost to their rival Mindelense on February 24, and is seventh with a small chance of a probable decisional matches and a very small chance of another relegation. Académica recently made a win over Castilho and has eight points and 13 goals. A week later, unexpectedly suffered a loss to Salamansa and had a small chance of relegation but a mid to high chance of decisional matches, a level inescapable up to the 13th round. Académica had 14 goals scored, fourth in the region alongside Castilho. Another loss the club suffered, it was to Batuque and had one last chance of escaping the relegation zone by the final round, partial or wholly with two more matches, a loss to Derby, then victory over Farense Fonte Filipe on March 30, Académica finished 7th and repeatedly headed to play in the division decisional matches with second placed [[ACDR Ponta d'Pom|Ponta d'Pom]]. On April 7, they defeated Ponta d'Pom 0-2 in the first leg, the second leg ended in a two goal draw, with 4 goals over 2, Académica became pleased that they will remain in the Premier Division next season. ===Appearance during late-Portuguese control=== Académica was the first champion of the [[Cape Verdean Football Championships|Cape Verdean Provincial (Colonial) Championships]] as they defeated [[Vitória FC (Cape Verde)|Vitória da Praia]] 2-0, the club also scored the first goals of the colonial era. The total was shared with Mindelense in 1954 and the totals became second behind that club from 1956, their totals was later shared with [[Sporting Clube da Praia|Sporting Praia]] in 1961 and [[Boavista FC (Cape Verde)|Boavista Praia]] two years later. Académica won another title in 1964 after defeating Sporting Praia 2-0 and won another title which remained second and it became two. Three years later, Académica Mindelo defeated Praia's [[CD Travadores|Travadores]] 2-0 in the 1967 championships and won their third and final provincial title, overall they were still second in totals. In 1972, Académica went for an attempt for another title which is being the last one during Portuguese rule. Once more they faced Travadores, the first leg ended in a double goal draw and lost the second leg 1-0 and the title, this was also their last appearance before independence three years later. Académica Mindelo scored a total of 9 goals at the provincial championships, one the second highest behind Mindelense.{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesk/kaapvchamp.html|title=List of champions of Cape Verde|publisher=RSSSF|accessdate=December 1, 2017}} ===National appearances=== After winning their 1987 regional title, the club competed in the national championships and lost a match and was knocked out. As Mindelense won the 1988 national title, Académica was runner-up and headed all the way to the 1989 finals to claim their only national title after defeating [[SC Santa Maria]] from the island of Sal. In 1995, Académica Mindelo was among the three clubs who entered the triangular phase, they included Boa Vista's [[Académica Operária]] and Santiago's [[Boavista FC (Cape Verde)|Boavista da Praia]]. The club never competed two matches as they withdrew and together with Académica Operária, lost the title to Boavista da Praia.[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesk/kaapv95.html Cape Verde Islands 1995], RSSSF Académica Mindelo enjoyed the [[2004 Cape Verdean Football Championships|2004]] season and had three wins, two draws and 11 points similarly to other clubs including Sal's [[Académico do Aeroporto]] and Boa Vista's [[Sport Sal Rei Club|Sal Rei]]. Sal Rei had 12 goals scored in the regular season coming second, the club had 11 goals scored and was immediately out of the competition. Académica do Mindelo had two draws first with Académico do Aeroporto at the first round with a goal, then a scoreless one with Sal Rei on May 22. The team won their tenth and final insular title and entered the national division in [[2007 Cape Verdean Football Championships|2007]], the club was first in Group A with 13 points and won four matches, and scored the most in the nation with 16 goals. After several years, the team managed to head into the finals and challenged their rival from the island of [[Santiago, Cape Verde|Santiago]] [[Sporting Clube da Praia]]. The first leg of the match was nil each and the second leg was tied at one. The most points went to the opponent and lost the national title to Sporting in mid-July, earlier than early-August. Académica fans were worried and did not celebrate the victory. Kadú scored the most goals at the nationals, numbering nine. ==Stadium== The club and plays in the [[Estádio Municipal Adérito Sena|Adérito Sena Stadium]] with a capacity of once served up to 4,000, now serves 5,000 after the renovation, it is named after one of the first players of the club Adérito Carvalho da Sena (1905–1970). [[CS Mindelense|Mindelense]], [[FC Derby]], [[GD Amarantes|Amarante]] and [[Batuque FC|Batuque]] are the other major clubs of the city and the island playing in that stadium along with [[GS Castilho]]. Batuque also trains at the stadium. ==Logo== Its logo is identical with Académica de Coimbra, the only difference is it has the letter M. It is also the logo for basketball and athletics. ==Uniform== The logo and the uniform as well as other teams with the name Académica and Académico in Cape Verde are identical to Académica de Coimbra. From 2015 to 2017, its clothing were supplied by MOAVE. Its clothing are currently supplied by Nike. {{Football kit box | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=|pattern_ra1= | leftarm1=FFFFFF|body1=FFFFFF|rightarm1=FFFFFF|shorts1=FFFFFF|socks1=FFFFFF | title = Home uniform until September 2017 }} {{Football kit box | pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2= | leftarm2=000000|body2=000000|rightarm2=000000|shorts2=000000|socks2=000000 | title = Visitor's uniform until September 2017 }} ==Rivalry== Académica's only rivalry is with [[CS Mindelense]], one of the longest in Cape Verde and the second longest in the region. After the creation of the regional division in 2008, the rivalry did not appear in one part of the early 2010s up until 2014 as Académica played in the Second Division. It appeared in other regional competitions. At the national rival, their rival was with [[Sporting Clube da Praia|Sporting Praia]] from the island of Santiago Sporting's rivalry with Académica Mindelo entirely disappeared today, a tiny part was the national championship restructuring for the upcoming 2017 season done in November 2015. ==Honours== * '''[[Cape Verdean football Championships|Cape Verdean Championship]]: 1''' **'''Before independence: 3''' :::1953, 1964, 1967http://www.zerozero.pt/equipa_historico.php?id=56755&view=1 **'''After Independence: 1''' ::: 1989 * '''[[São Vicente Premier Division|São Vicente Island Championships/Premier Division]]: 10''' :: 1948, 1953, 1963, 1964, 1967, 1972, 1986/87, 1994/95, 2003/04, 2006/07 * '''[[São Vicente SuperCup]]: 1''' :: 2006/07 * '''[[São Vicente Association Cup|São Vicente Opening Tournament/Association Cup]]: 2''' :: 2001/02, 2006/07 ==League and cup history== ===Provincial era=== {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#efefef;" ! '''Combined''' is an event in [[Alpine skiing|alpine ski racing]]. A traditional combined competition consists of one run of [[Downhill (ski competition)|downhill]] and two runs of [[Slalom skiing|slalom]], each discipline run on separate days. The winner is the skier with the fastest aggregate time. (Until the 1990s, a complicated point system was used to determine placings in the combined event.) A modified version, the super combined, is a speed race (downhill or [[super-G]]) and only one run of slalom, with both portions scheduled on the same day. ==History== The first [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships|World Championships]] in [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 1931|1931]] did not include the combined event, but it was added to the program in [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 1932|1932]]. [[Alpine skiing at the Winter Olympics]] was not included until [[Alpine skiing at the 1936 Winter Olympics|1936]], and the combined was the only event. The combined was one of three medal events at the next Olympics in [[Alpine skiing at the 1948 Winter Olympics|1948]], along with downhill and slalom. The combined used the results of the only downhill race with two runs of combined slalom. The regular slalom (two runs) was held the following day. With the introduction of [[giant slalom]] at the world championships in [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 1950|1950]], the combined event disappeared from the Olympics for four decades, until re-introduced in [[Alpine skiing at the 1988 Winter Olympics|1988]]. From 1948 through [[Alpine skiing at the 1980 Winter Olympics|1980]], the Winter Olympics also served as the world championships, with two sets of medals awarded. The world champion in the combined was determined "on paper" by the results of the three races of downhill, giant slalom, and slalom. The top three finishers in the combined event were awarded world championship medals by the FIS, but not Olympic medals from the [[International Olympic Committee|IOC]]. This three-race paper method was used from [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 1954|1954]] through 1980; no FIS medals were awarded for the combined in 1950 or [[Alpine skiing at the 1952 Winter Olympics|1952]]. A separate downhill and slalom for the combined event was added to the world championships in [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 1982|1982]], and the Olympics in 1988. The world championships were held annually from 1931 through [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 1939|1939]], were interrupted by [[World War II]], and resumed as a biennial event at the 1948 Olympics, held in even-numbered years through 1982. They skipped the [[Alpine skiing at the 1984 Winter Olympics|1984 Olympics]] and have been scheduled for odd-numbered years since [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 1985|1985]]. (The [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 1995|1995]] event was postponed to [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 1996|1996]], due to lack of snow in southeastern [[Spain]].) At the Winter Olympics and world championships, the slalom and downhill portions of a combined event are run separately from the regular downhill and slalom events on shorter, and often less demanding, race courses. On the [[FIS Alpine Ski World Cup|World Cup]] circuit, traditional combined events have been "paper races," combining skiers' times from a separately scheduled downhill race and slalom race, generally held at the same location over two days. In 2005, the FIS began to replace these "calculated" combineds with super combined events, held on one day, which administrators hope will result in increased participation.{{cite magazine |url=http://skiracing.com/stories/fis-spring-calendar-conference-highlights/ |magazine=Ski Racing |last=Rugh |first=Pete |title=FIS Spring Calendar Conference Highlights |date= May 10, 2005 |accessdate=March 4, 2014}} ==Super Combined== A modified version, the super combined, is a speed race (downhill or [[super-G]]) and only one run of slalom, with both portions scheduled on the same day. ===World Cup=== The first super combined was a World Cup race held in [[2005 Alpine Skiing World Cup|2005]] in [[Lauberhorn|Wengen]], [[Switzerland]], on January 14th; [[Benjamin Raich]] of [[Austria]] was the winner. The first women's race in the new format was run six weeks later in [[San Sicario Fraiteve|San Sicario]], [[Italy]]; won by [[Croatia]]'s [[Janica Kostelić]] on February 27th. The [[2006 Alpine Skiing World Cup|2006]] World Cup calendar included three super combineds and just one traditional combined race on the men's side, while the women raced two super combineds and no traditional combineds. Kostelić won the first three women's World Cup super combineds. Beginning with the [[2007 Alpine Skiing World Cup|2007]] season, the FIS began awarding a fifth discipline-champion "crystal globe" to the points winner of combined races; the 2007 season included five combined races for each gender.{{cite magazine|url=http://skiracing.com/stories/2006-07-world-cup-award-super-combined-crystal-globe/ |magazine=Ski Racing |last=Rugh |first=Pete |title=2006-07 World Cup to award super combined crystal globe |date=April 17, 2006 |accessdate=March 4, 2014}} Nine out of the ten scheduled combineds use the new super-combined format, the only exception was [[Hahnenkamm, Kitzbühel|Kitzbühel]], [[Austria]], which continued with the traditional two-run format (K), albeit in a "paper race." The change to super combined expectedly resulted in major disapproval from the slalom specialists, the loudest critic being [[Ivica Kostelić]]. Even with the change to a single slalom run, many speed skiers believe the technical racers have the advantage in the super combined.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/02/13/olympics-alpineskiing-combined-idUSL5N0LI22D20140213 |publisher=Reuters |last=Breidthardt |first=Annika |title=Olympics-Alpine skiing-Downhill champion Mayer scorns super-combined format |date=February 13, 2014 |accessdate=March 4, 2014}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/16/sports/for-some-ski-racers-an-advantage-before-the-season-even-starts.html?_r=0 |newspaper=New York Times |last=McMillan |first=Kelley |title=For some ski racers, an advantage before the season even starts |date=January 15, 2014 |accessdate=March 4, 2014}} ===World Championships and Winter Olympics=== The super combined format debuted at the world championships in [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 2007|2007]] in [[Åre Ski Area|Åre]], [[Sweden]], and at the Winter Olympics in [[Alpine skiing at the 2010 Winter Olympics|2010]] at [[Whistler Blackcomb|Whistler]], [[Canada]]. ==Men's World Cup podiums== In the following table men's combined (super combined from 2007) [[Alpine Ski World Cup|World Cup]] podiums in the World Cup since first edition in 1976.{{cite web|url=https://data.fis-ski.com/alpine-skiing/cup-standings.html?suchen=true&export_standing=&suchcompetitorid=&suchseason=1976&suchgender=M&suchnation=§or=AL&suchcup=WC&discipline=KB&search=Search|title=CUP STANDING ALPINE SKIING WORLD CUP 1976 MEN - COMBINED|publisher=fis-ski.com|accessdate=11 February 2018}} {{legend|palegreen|No trophy}} {| class="wikitable sortable" width=60% style="font-size:90%; text-align:left;" ! {{About|the arena located in Sunrise, Florida|information about the skyscraper in Charlotte, North Carolina|BB&T Center|the arena at Northern Kentucky University|BB&T Arena|the amphitheater in New Jersey|BB&T Pavilion}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = BB&T Center | logo_image = [[File:BB&T_Center_logo.png|125px]] | image = [[Image:BankAtlanticCenterCrop.JPG|center|250px|The BB&T Center located in Sunrise, Florida]] | caption = BB&T Center | address = 1 Panther Parkway | location = [[Sunrise, Florida]] | coordinates = {{Coord|26|9|30|N|80|19|32|W|type:landmark_scale:4000|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = {{Start date|1996|11|08}} | opened = {{Start date|1998|10|03}} | owner = [[Broward County, Florida]] | operator = Arena Operating Company, Ltd. | construction_cost = US$185 million{{cite web |title=Facts and Figures|url=http://www.bankatlanticcenter.com/about/FactsandFigures.asp|publisher=BB&T Center|accessdate=October 22, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208140316/http://www.bankatlanticcenter.com/about/FactsandFigures.asp|archivedate=February 8, 2012|deadurl=yes}}

*Theatre: 3,000 [https://groups.google.com/forum/#!search/sinatra$20attendance|sort:relevance/rec.music.artists.kiss/u5PKtwrBaZ0/GlbiTgdwp9gJ BankAtlantic Center] | dimensions = {{convert|872000|sqft|m2}} | parking = 7,045 total spaces | website = {{URL|http://www.thebbtcenter.com}} }} The '''BB&T Center''' (previously known as the '''National Car Rental Center''', '''Office Depot Center''', and '''BankAtlantic Center''') is an [[list of indoor arenas|indoor arena]] located in [[Sunrise, Florida]]. It is the home venue for the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL)'s [[Florida Panthers]]. It was completed in 1998, at a cost of US$185 million, almost entirely publicly financed, and features 70 suites and 2,623 club seats. ==History== [[File:BB&TCenterAerial.jpg|left|thumb|An aerial shot of the BB&T Center]] In 1992, [[Wayne Huizenga]] obtained a new NHL franchise that would eventually become the Florida Panthers. Until the team had an arena of their own, they initially played at the now-demolished [[Miami Arena]], sharing the venue with the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]'s [[Miami Heat]].{{cite news |title=N.H.L. Is Going to Disneyland, and South Florida, Too|first=Joe|last=Lapointe|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/11/sports/hockey-nhl-is-going-to-disneyland-and-south-florida-too.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 11, 1992|accessdate=February 19, 2015}} [[Sunrise, Florida|Sunrise]] City Manager Pat Salerno made public a $167-million financing and construction plan for a [[civic center]] near the [[Sawgrass Expressway]] in December 1995,{{cite news |title=Sunrise Gets Serious About Arena|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1995-12-16/news/9512150291_1_civic-center-bed-tax-salerno|newspaper=[[Sun-Sentinel|South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]|location=Fort Lauderdale|date=December 16, 1995|accessdate=February 19, 2015}} and [[Broward County, Florida|Broward County]] approved construction in February 1996.{{cite news |title=Prospects Good For Broward Arena|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1996-02-01/news/9601310426_1_arena-plans-broward-county-bed-tax|newspaper=[[Sun-Sentinel|South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]|location=Fort Lauderdale|date=February 1, 1996|accessdate=February 19, 2015}} In June 1996, the site was chosen by the Panthers, and in July, Alex Muxo gathered more than a dozen architects, engineers and contractors for the first major design brainstorming session. Architects [[Ellerbe Becket]] were given 26 months to build the arena, which had to be ready by August 30, 1998, to accommodate the [[1998–99 NHL season]]. Despite never having designed a facility that had taken less than 31 months from start to finish, they accepted the job.{{cite web |title=Panthers History: Arenas|url=http://panthers.nhl.com/club/page.htm?id=61370|publisher=National Hockey League|accessdate=February 19, 2015}} Seventy suites were completed with [[wet bar]]s, closed circuit monitors and leather upholstery. Averaging over {{convert|650|sqft|m2}}, the suites are the largest in the country for this type of facility. All the activity was generated by over 50 subcontractors and 2.3 million man hours without a single injury. Known as Broward County Civic Center during construction, the [[naming rights]] were won in July 1998 by [[National Car Rental]]—a company purchased by Huizenga in January 1997—leading to the venue being named the National Car Rental Center.{{cite news |title=Huizenga's National Car Rental To Be Name Gracing Hockey Arena|first1=Alan|last1=Snell|first2=David|last2=Fleshler|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1998-07-11/news/9807110071_1_huizenga-rights-deal-team-s-new-arena|newspaper=[[Sun-Sentinel|South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]|location=Fort Lauderdale|date=July 11, 1998|accessdate=February 19, 2015}} A [[certificate of occupancy]] was given on September 12, and the arena opened on October 3 with a [[Celine Dion]] concert. The next day, [[Elton John]] performed, and on October 9 the Panthers had their first home game at the new arena.{{cite news |title=Sunrise Arena Ok'd For Occupancy|first=Robert|last=Nolin|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1998-09-12/news/9809120035_1_new-arena-permanent-certificate-occupancy|newspaper=[[Sun-Sentinel|South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]|location=Fort Lauderdale|date=September 12, 1998|accessdate=February 19, 2015}} As NRC's new parent company [[ANC Rental]] went bankrupt in 2002, the Panthers sought a new sponsor for the arena.{{cite news |title=Panthers Want Car Rental Name Taken Off Arena|first=Sarah|last=Talalay|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2002-08-16/news/0208160136_1_anc-rental-corp-panthers-car|newspaper=[[Sun-Sentinel|South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]|location=Fort Lauderdale|date=August 16, 2002|accessdate=February 19, 2015}} It later became the [[Office Depot]] Center in the summer of 2002, and the BankAtlantic Center on September 6, 2005. As [[BB&T]] purchased [[BankAtlantic]] in July 2012, two months later the arena was rebranded as BB&T Center.{{cite press release|title=BB&T Center Naming Rights Headline Long-term Florida Panthers-BB&T Partnership|url=https://www.nhl.com/panthers/news/bb-t-center-naming-rights-headline-long-term-florida-panthers-bb-t-partnership/c-641153|publisher=Florida Panthers|website=NHL.com|date=September 10, 2012|accessdate=February 24, 2018}}{{cite news |title=Florida Panthers’ Arena Now BB&T Center|first=George|last=Richards|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/09/11/2995653/florida-panthers-arena-takes-bbt.html|newspaper=[[The Miami Herald]]|date=September 11, 2012|accessdate=February 19, 2015}} BB&T Center is currently the largest arena in Florida and second-largest in the Southeastern United States, behind [[Greensboro Coliseum]]. During the 2011 offseason, the BB&T Center replaced the original green seats in the lower bowl with new red seats, as a part of the Panthers' "We See Red" campaign.{{cite web |title=Panthers See Red In BankAtlantic Center Lower Bowl|url=http://panthers.nhl.com/club/news.htm?id=569939|publisher=National Hockey League|date=July 25, 2011|accessdate=February 19, 2015}} In October 2012, Sunrise Sports and Entertainment completed installation of the Club Red seating sections encompassing the center ice seats during hockey games. It is an all-inclusive nightclub experience following the trend of other sports and entertainment venues in incorporating high-end seating sections and clubs.{{cite news |title=Club Red elevates experiences at BB&T Center|first=Miriam|last=Valverde|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2013-01-29/news/fl-panthers-club-red-20130123_1_hockey-fans-bb-t-center-hockey-game|newspaper=[[Sun-Sentinel|South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]|location=Fort Lauderdale|date=January 29, 2013|accessdate=February 19, 2015}} The ADT Club located on the club level offers food and beverage. The Duffy's Sky Club at the BB&T Center encompasses approximately 8,000 square feet and caters to approximately 500 guests. The Penalty Box offers fans another seating and dining option inside the BB&T Center. The Legends Lounge is a restaurant located on the Lexus Suite Level and offers sit down service.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} The BB&T Center is also the home for private lounge box seating. On May 14, 2013, Broward County voted to fund a new scoreboard for the county-owned BB&T Center{{cite news |title=County to Fund New Scoreboard for Panthers Arena|first=Robert|last=Nolin|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2013-05-14/news/fl-commission-arena-20130514_1_new-scoreboard-panthers-arena-panthers-president-michael-yormark|newspaper=[[Sun-Sentinel|South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]|location=Fort Lauderdale|date=May 14, 2013|accessdate=February 19, 2015}} On October 11, 2013, the scoreboard made its debut for the Panthers' 2013–14 home opener.{{cite news |title=Huizenga Joins Viola to Christen New Panthers Era Before 6-3 Win|first=Craig|last=Davis|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2013-10-11/sports/sfl-huizenga-viola-christen-new-panthers-era-20131011_1_jonathan-huberdeau-aleksander-barkov-jacob-markstrom|newspaper=[[Sun-Sentinel|South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]|location=Fort Lauderdale|date=October 11, 2013|accessdate=February 19, 2015}} ==Regular events== [[Image:BankAtlantic Center2.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Inside the Bank Atlantic Center during a Florida Panthers game.]] In addition to the Panthers, the arena was formerly home to the [[Miami Majesty|Florida Pit Bulls]] of the [[American Basketball Association (2000–present)|American Basketball Association]], the [[Miami Caliente]] of the [[Lingerie Football League]], and the [[Florida Bobcats]] of the [[Arena Football League|AFL]], along with the only season of the [[Florida ThunderCats]]. This arena also serves as the host for the Orange Bowl Basketball Classic held every December in conjunction with the [[Orange Bowl|namesake college football game]]. The arena has also hosted the [[53rd National Hockey League All-Star Game|2003 NHL All-Star Game]] and the 2006 ABA All-Star game. ==Concerts== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! width=12% style="text-align:center;background:#FFFFFF;border-top:#C8102E 5px solid;border-bottom:#041E42 5px solid;"| Date ! width=10% style="text-align:center;background:#FFFFFF;border-top:#C8102E 5px solid;border-bottom:#041E42 5px solid;"| Artist ! width=10% style="text-align:center;background:#FFFFFF;border-top:#C8102E 5px solid;border-bottom:#041E42 5px solid;"| Opening act(s) ! width=16% style="text-align:center;background:#FFFFFF;border-top:#C8102E 5px solid;border-bottom:#041E42 5px solid;"| Tour / Concert name ! width=10% style="text-align:center;background:#FFFFFF;border-top:#C8102E 5px solid;border-bottom:#041E42 5px solid;"| Attendance ! width=10% style="text-align:center;background:#FFFFFF;border-top:#C8102E 5px solid;border-bottom:#041E42 5px solid;"| Revenue ! width=20% style="text-align:center;background:#FFFFFF;border-top:#C8102E 5px solid;border-bottom:#041E42 5px solid;"| Notes |- | October 3, 1998 || [[Celine Dion]] || [[André-Philippe Gagnon]] || [[Let's Talk About Love World Tour]] || — || — || Arena's inaugural event |- | March 30, 1999 || [[Marilyn Manson (band)|Marilyn Manson]] || [[Jack Off Jill]] || [[Rock Is Dead Tour]] || — || — || Homecoming concert |- | December 31, 1999 || [[Bee Gees]] || — || — || — || — || It was to be their last full arena concert as a group |- | October 4, 2000|| [[Sarah Brightman]] || — || [[La Luna World Tour]] || — || — || The concert was recorded and released for PBS as well as video in VHS and later on DVD, entitled [[La Luna: Live in Concert]]. |- | January 22–24, 2001 || [[Backstreet Boys]] || [[Myra (singer)|Myra]]

The Western Conference defeated the Eastern Conference, 6-5, in a shootout victory. It marked the first "official" shootout in the NHL. ===Boxing, mixed martial arts=== The arena has held [[boxing]] and [[mixed martial arts]] events such as [[EliteXC: Heat]] featuring the main event of [[Seth Petruzelli]] and [[Kimbo Slice]] took place on October 4, 2008. On February 15, 2009, a lightweight bout between [[Nate Campbell]] and Ali Funeka took place in the arena. [[Strikeforce (mixed martial arts)|Strikeforce]] MMA made their debut at the arena on January 30, 2010, with the [[Strikeforce: Miami]] event on [[Showtime (TV channel)|Showtime]].{{cite web |url=http://mmajunkie.com/news/16928/strikeforce-to-florida-in-2010-with-cristiane-cyborg-santos-and-herschel-walker.mma |title=Strikeforce to Florida in 2010 with Cristiane "Cyborg" Santos and Herschel Walker |publisher=mmajunkie.com |date=2009-11-19 |accessdate=2009-11-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013140249/http://mmajunkie.com/news/16928/strikeforce-to-florida-in-2010-with-cristiane-cyborg-santos-and-herschel-walker.mma |archive-date=2012-10-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }} [[2012 in UFC#UFC on FX: Johnson vs. McCall|UFC on FX 3]] took place at the arena on June 8, 2012. It was the first [[Ultimate Fighting Championship|UFC]] event ever held at the arena.{{cite web |url=http://mmajunkie.com/news/28122/ufc-on-fx-3-heads-to-fort-lauderdales-bankatlantic-center-on-june-8.mma |title=UFC on FX 3 heads to Fort Lauderdale's BankAtlantic Center on June 8 |publisher=MMAJunkie.com |date=April 5, 2012 |accessdate=April 5, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120407013104/http://mmajunkie.com/news/28122/ufc-on-fx-3-heads-to-fort-lauderdales-bankatlantic-center-on-june-8.mma |archive-date=2012-04-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ===Professional wrestling=== *[[WCW]] [[Bash at the Beach (1999)|Bash At The Beach]] - July 11, 1999 *[[WWE|WWF]] [[Armageddon (1999)|Armageddon]] – December 12, 1999 *WWE [[Armageddon (2002)|Armageddon]] – December 15, 2002 ===Rodeo=== The [[Professional Bull Riders]] brought their [[Built Ford Tough Series]] tour to the BB&T Center in September 2005 for a [[bull riding]] event, which was won by Kody Lostroh (who ultimately became the Rookie of the Year that same year). ===Other events=== *On May 23, 2008, Senator [[Barack Obama]] held a rally as part of his presidential campaign. *On October 29, 2008, Senator Barack Obama held a rally as part of his presidential campaign, and addressed the nation live on several television networks. *On August 10, 2016, [[Donald Trump]] held a rally as part of his presidential campaign, and addressed the nation live on several television networks. *On February 21, 2018, the venue hosted a [[CNN]] Town Hall on gun control in response to the [[Stoneman Douglas High School shooting]]; it was attended by 7,000 people, including survivors of the shooting and relatives of the victims.{{cite news |last1=Man |first1=Anthony |last2=Barszewski |first2=Larry |date=February 21, 2018 |title=Rubio is jeered as CNN town hall meeting about Florida school shooting turns angry |url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/politics/fl-florida-school-shooting-cnn-town-hall-20180220-story.html |work=Sun-Sentinel |accessdate=February 21, 2018}} *On June 27, 2018, rapper [[XXXTentacion]]'s fan memorial and public funeral was held at the center.{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} ==Arena information== ===Seating=== *[[Basketball]]: 20,737 *[[ice hockey|Hockey]]: 19,250 *End-Stage [[Concert]]s: 15,207 – 23,000 *Center-Stage [[Concert]]s: 25,000 *{{convert|17000|sqft|m2|-2}} of arena floor space for trade shows and other events such as circuses and ice shows. ===Parking and loading docks=== *Total: 7,045 Spaces ''(Does not include production or bus/oversized vehicle parking)'' *General Parking: 4,787 Spaces *Suite/Club Seat Parking: 1,430 Spaces *Garage: 226 Spaces *Disabled Parking: 90 Spaces *Event Staff: 512 Spaces *Truck Doors: 5 *Waste Removal Docks: 2 ===Food and novelty concessions=== *Plaza Level: 3 Food Courts and Pantherland Retail *Mezzanine Level: 3 Food Courts and two Points of Purchase Kiosks ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|BB&T Center (Sunrise)}} * [http://www.thebbtcenter.com BB&T Center] * [http://footage.shutterstock.com/clip-6104555 BB&T Center aerial video] {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Florida Panthers]] | years = 1998 – present | before = [[Miami Arena]] | after = current }} {{succession box | title = Host of the
[[National Hockey League All-Star Game|NHL All-Star Game]] | years = 2003 | before = [[Staples Center]] | after = [[Xcel Energy Center]] }} {{end}} {{NHL Arenas}} {{LFL Venues}} {{Florida Panthers}} {{Florida Bobcats}} {{Music venues of Florida}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bankatlantic Center}} [[Category:1998 establishments in Florida]] [[Category:Arena football venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Broward County, Florida]] [[Category:Florida Panthers arenas]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Florida]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Florida]] [[Category:Indoor soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:Legends Football League venues]] [[Category:Music venues completed in 1998]] [[Category:Music venues in Florida]] [[Category:National Hockey League venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1998]] [[Category:Sports venues in Miami]] [[Category:Sunrise, Florida]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Black Irish | image = Black irish post.jpg | caption = Promotional poster | director = [[Brad Gann]] | writer = [[Brad Gann]] | starring = [[Michael Angarano]]
[[Brendan Gleeson]]
[[Tom Guiry]]
[[Melissa Leo]]
[[Emily VanCamp]] | producer = [[J. Todd Harris]]
[[Kelly Crean]]
[[Jeff Orenstein]]
[[Mark Donadio]] | cinematography = [[Michael Fimognari]] | distributor = [[Anywhere Road]] | released = {{Film date|2007|07|26}} | country = United States | gross = $6,900 (USA)http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=blackirish.htm | language = English }} '''''Black Irish''''' is a 2007 drama film written and directed by [[Brad Gann]]. ==Plot== Sixteen-year-old Cole McKay’s struggle for independence is put to the test as his [[South Boston]] [[Irish-Catholic]] family implodes around him. Older brother Terry is descending into a life of drugs and crime, pregnant sister Kathleen is being sent away to cover up the shame of unwed motherhood and Cole’s father, Desmond, spends his days in a fog of alcohol and self-pity, silently torturing himself over what might have been. The one thing keeping young Cole’s head above water is his love of baseball. The movie starts with Cole practicing his pitching, when he is picked up by his family to attend the funeral of Desmond's sister. A talented [[baseball pitcher]], Cole overcomes self-doubt and family indifference to fight his way into the state championships. To get there however, he must make a life and death decision, one that will change the McKay family forever. ==Cast== *[[Michael Angarano]] as Cole McKay *[[Brendan Gleeson]] as Desmond McKay *[[Tom Guiry]] as Terry McKay *[[Melissa Leo]] as Margaret McKay *[[Emily VanCamp]] as Kathleen McKay *[[Michael Rispoli]] as Joey *[[Francis Capra]] as Anthony *[[Mark S. Cartier]] as Mr. Quint ==Release== *The film premiered at the [[Newport Beach Film Festival]] on 20 April 2007. It received a [[limited release]], opening in Los Angeles, New York City and Boston on 26 October 2007. It was released on DVD on 8 January 2008 in the US and Canada. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0455915|title=Black Irish}} *{{mojo title|id=blackirish|title=Black Irish}} *{{rotten-tomatoes|id=10008667-black_irish|title=Black Irish}} *[http://www.blackirishmovie.com/ Official Site] *[https://www.myspace.com/blackirishmovie/ Official Myspace Site] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070929083917/http://one.revver.com/watch/237078/flv/affiliate/72261 Official Movie Trailer] {{DEFAULTSORT:Black Irish (Film)}} [[Category:2007 films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:2000s sports films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Films set in Boston]] [[Category:Irish-American media]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:American baseball films]] [[Category:Films about dysfunctional families]] {{2000s-drama-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{coord|41.5885|-93.6195|region:US-IA|display=title}} {{Infobox Stadium |stadium_name = Des Moines Coliseum |image = [[Image:DesMoinesColiseum.PNG|300px]] |location = [[Des Moines, Iowa]] |opened = 1908 |closed = August 13, 1949 |demolished = August 13, 1949 |owner = |operator = |surface = |construction_cost = |architect = |tenants = [[Drake University]] |seating_capacity =}} The '''Des Moines Coliseum''' was a building located in [[Des Moines, Iowa]]. Opened in 1908, it served as the main venue for large public events in Des Moines for four decades. [[Herbert Hoover]] launched his 1932 re-election campaign from the Coliseum, and several other U.S. Presidents spoke there, including [[Woodrow Wilson]], [[Theodore Roosevelt]], and [[William Howard Taft]]. [[Drake University]] played basketball in the Coliseum for a number of years, and it was used for wrestling, boxing, ice skating, and circus events. It was destroyed by fire on August 13, 1949. A YMCA was later built on the site, but that was torn down in 2015 and the site now sits empty (as of 2016).
==External links== *[http://ddr.lib.drake.edu/cdm4/item_viewer.php?CISOROOT=/du-hdm&CISOPTR=213&DMSCALE=50&DMWIDTH=600&DMHEIGHT=600&DMX=0&DMY=0&DMMODE=viewer&DMTEXT=&REC=11&DMTHUMB=1&DMROTATE=0 Picture of the Des Moines Coliseum] *[http://www.desmoinesregister.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/99999999/ENT/502270317 Date of fire] *[http://www.linngroveiowa.org/ColiseumDesMoines.jpg Painting of the front of the Des Moines Coliseum]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company |name = Fantazzle Fantasy Sports |logo = Press release distribution 0155073 25957.jpg |logo_size = 300px |type = |traded_as = |industry = [[Fantasy Sports]], [[Daily Fantasy Sports]] |foundation = |founder = |location_city = |location_country = |area_served = Worldwide |key_people = Ryan Parr (CEO) |products = |revenue = |operating_income = |net_income = |assets = |equity = |num_employees = |subsid = |homepage = {{URL|http://www.Fantazzle.com/|Fantazzle.com}} }} '''Fantazzle''' was a fantasy sports website that allowed users to play daily, weekly, and seasonal fantasy sports games. Some of the games they offered were free, while others required a monetary deposit. Every game Fantazzle offered resulted in an immediate cash prize. The website has since been shut down.
==History== Fantazzle launched in September 2008. They are members of the [[Fantasy Sports Trade Association]] (FSTA). In January 2009, Fantazzle was recognized jointly by the FSTA and the Fantasy Football Librarian as the winner of the 2008 Fantasy Football Projection Accuracy Challenge in its first year.<ref name="press">"Press Release - Fantazzle Fantasy Sports Games Announces Schedule for the 2011-2012 Fantasy Football and College Fantasy Football Season!" Press Release Service and Distribution - 24-7PressRelease.com. 14 Aug. 2011. Web. 03 Jan. 2012. <http://www.24-7pressrelease.com/press-release-rss/fantazzle-fantasy-sports-games-announces-schedule-for-the-20112012-fantasy-football-and-college-fantasy-football-season-229547.php>.</ref>
In 2010, Fantazzle released a [[white paper]] on the impact of [[fantasy sports]] has on [[Counterproductive work behavior|workplace]] productivity. With multiple sources and facts, Fantazzle stated that [[fantasy sports]] did not slow down workplace productivity. They proposed that many businesses are not negatively affected by employees engaging in the activity. The [[white papers]] went on to say that fantasy sports have proved to be a valuable [[team-building|team building]] exercise that leads to increased employee [[loyalty]].<ref>Pearson, Zack. "Fantazzle Releases White Paper on Fantasy Games in the Workplace." FantasyFootballSportal.com. 16 Dec. 2010. Web. 25 Jan. 2012. <http://www.fantasyfootballsportal.com/fantasy-football/fantazzle-releases-white-paper-fantasy-games-workplace/>.</ref>
In 2010, Fantazzle picked up a sponsorship from current [[Baltimore Ravens]] running back [[Ray Rice]]. Ray Rice had this to say about Fantazzle: "Wanted you all to check out Fantazzle Fantasy Games. Fantazzle has cool fantasy games for baseball, racing, golf and, of course, football. In the upcoming months, we'll have a Ray Rice fantasy football game I'll be sponsoring with free autographed and cash prizes.”<ref>"Press Release - Fantazzle Fantasy Sports, Ray Rice of the Baltimore Ravens, and CurvSports.com Announce a New Sponsorship for Fantazzle's Fantasy Football Games and Fantasy Sports Games Site." Press Release Service and Distribution - 24-7PressRelease.com. 8 June 2010. Web. 24 Jan. 2012. <http://www.24-7pressrelease.com/press-release/fantazzle-fantasy-sports-ray-rice-of-the-baltimore-ravens-and-curvsportscom-announce-a-new-sponsorship-for-fantazzles-fantasy-football-games-and-fantasy-sports-games-site-155073.php>.</ref> Later in 2010, Fantazzle worked with the then-[[New York Giants]] receiver and current [[St. Louis Rams|St. Louis Ram]] [[Steve Smith (wide receiver, born 1985)|Steve Smith]] in a push to have him voted into the [[Pro Bowl]]. Fantazzle offered merchandise autographed by Steve Smith to those that won select fantasy games.<ref>"Fantasy Football Promotion | Fantasy Football Games - Fantazzle Fantasy Sports." Fantasy Basketball Games | Fantasy Football Playoff Game | Fantazzle.com. Fantazzle Fantasy Sports, 2010. Web. 24 Jan. 2012. <http://www.fantazzle.com/fantasy-football-promotion.php>.</ref>
==Games== Fantazzle offers [[Fantasy football (American)|fantasy football]], [[fantasy baseball]], fantasy soccer, [[fantasy basketball]], [[fantasy golf]], fantasy racing, [[fantasy hockey]], fantasy poker, and fantasy games for [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|March Madness]]. In 2011, Fantazzle became one of the first daily fantasy sports websites to offer [[college football]] fantasy games.<ref>"Weekly Fantasy Games | Daily Fantasy Games - Fantazzle Fantasy Sports." Fantasy Baseball Games | College Fantasy Football | Fantasy Football Games. Web. 03 Jan. 2012. <http://www.fantazzle.com/first-time-here.php>.</ref> Fantazzle also added fantasy games for the [[Lingerie Football League]] in 2011.<ref>"Fantazzle and LFL Ready for ‘Opening Night’ Game, Friday, August 26th." Fantazzle Blog. Fantazzle Fantasy Sports, 24 Aug. 2011. Web. 6 Jan. 2012. <http://www.fantazzleblog.com/2011/08/fantazzle-and-lfl-ready-for-%E2%80%98opening-night%E2%80%99-game-friday-august-26th/>.</ref>
===Game Formats=== Fantazzle offers daily games, weekly games, twice-a-week games, monthly games, and season-long games. In addition to traditional fantasy sports formats, Fantazzle offers a Pick ‘em game, which allows users to choose different players that are matched up one-on-one with another similar player for a particular stat. Users would then pick which player will have a better performance in that stat. For example, one quarterback would be matched up against another quarterback, and touchdown passes would be compared. If the user chose QB1, who ended up passing for 100 yards and 2 TD, and QB2 passed for 200 yards and 1 TD, then the user would win, because only touchdown passes counted for that matchup. These matchups can be with any position and any sport.<ref name="press" />
==Affiliated websites== Fantazzle is also affiliated with a number of blogs, including Weekly Fantasy Sportal, Fantasy Football Sportal, and Fantasy Baseball Sportal. These blogs are updated periodically to give users fantasy sports advice. Fantazzle also offers a [[podcast]], in which discussions on different [[fantasy sports]] are discussed.<ref>Parr, Ryan. "Fantasy Football Games Podcast." Fantazzle Blog. Fantazzle Fantasy Sports, 13 Dec. 2009. Web. 06 Jan. 2012. <http://www.fantazzleblog.com/2009/12/fantasy-football-podcast-midnight-oil/>.</ref>
== References == <references />
[[Category:Fantasy sports]] [[Category:Sport websites]]
