[[File:Longboarding Downhill.jpg|thumb|Riding a longboard in Los Angeles, CA]] '''Longboarding''' is the act of riding on a [[Longboard (skateboard)|longboard]]. A longboard varies in shape and size unlike its set counterpart, the [[skateboard]], and has more stability, traction and durability due to larger wheel size and lower wheel [[durometer]]s. Many, but not all longboards, use trucks (axles) that contain different geometric parameters than a skateboard as well. These factors and their variation have given way to a variety of disciplines, functions and purposes for a longboard. Longboarding also has competitive races down hill where some riders reach speeds exceeding 60 miles per hour. The angles at which some longboards can turn, as well as their ability to coast long distances make them more suitable for cruising and commuting on streets than regular skateboards. [[File:Longboarding in the snow, East Wenatchee Washington.jpg|thumb|Large grippy wheels and sealed boards often made from weather resistant material like bamboo make longboarding possible in any season, anywhere unlike typical skateboards.]]
==History== The life of longboarding started in the 1950s.<ref name="sportsthenandnow.com">{{Cite web|title = The History of Longboarding {{!}} Sports Then and Now|url = http://sportsthenandnow.com/2014/02/10/the-history-of-longboarding/|accessdate = 2015-09-30}}</ref> The idea of longboarding originated from surfers in Hawaii. They wanted to bring their surfing hobby to land when the waves were too small to surf.<ref name="sportsthenandnow.com"/> Surfers then figured out a way of achieving their goal of bringing surfing to land by customizing their skateboards. They would grab a piece of thick [[plywood]] and shape it into a smaller version of a [[surfboard]], then screw the trucks and wheels to the decks and head out to small hills to imitate the same moves they would do if they were out surfing.
During the 1970s, a small group of longboarders honed their techniques. Some longboarders from this period were profiled in a 1978 SkateBoarder magazine article entitled ''Cult of the Longboard''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gillogly|first1=Brian|title=The Cult of the Longboard|date=1978}}</ref> These pioneers saw longboarding as a form of self-expression, and were influenced by [[surfing]]. However, despite the advent of [[polyurethane]] wheels (referred to as "thane" by longboarders<ref>{{cite web|title=Longboard Lingo - The Complete Guide to Longboard Slang|url=http://stokedskateboards.com/knowledge-base/longboard-terminology/longboard-slang|website=Stoked Skateboards|accessdate=10 August 2014}}</ref>), longboarding did not reach a high degree of prevalence during the 1970s.<ref name=brooke168-9>{{cite book|last1=Brooke|first1=Michael|title=The concrete wave : the history of skateboarding|date=2003|publisher=Warwick|location=Toronto, Ont.|isbn=1894020545|pages=168–169|edition=5th printing|chapter=Carving, cruising, and bombing: the story of longboarding}}</ref>
Longboarding lived on as an underground sport with home hobbyists continuing to make boards in their garages or strap trucks onto snowboard decks using old Kryptonic wheels from the 1970s or roller skating wheels.{{citation needed|date=August 2014}}
In the early 1990s, [[Sector 9]] started mass-producing and selling longboards.<ref name=brooke169-70>{{cite book|last1=Brooke|first1=Michael|title=The concrete wave : the history of skateboarding|date=2003|publisher=Warwick|location=Toronto, Ont.|isbn=1894020545|pages=169–170|edition=5th printing|chapter=Carving, cruising, and bombing: the story of longboarding}}</ref> The 1990s also saw a change in truck technology: reverse kingpins made longboarding more stable.{{citation needed|date=August 2014}}
The Internet has made it possible for small groups of skateboarders to communicate with each other and also gain an audience they might not have had locally, allowing the sport to grow further.{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} Multiple subbranches of longboarding exist with relatively small but hardcore groups of adherents like slalom, LDP (long distance pushing/pumping), downhill, dance, freeriding, technical hardwheel sliding and more.
Besides diversifying into many "species", longboarding itself has also come back around full circle. It now has begun embracing more street oriented tricks and cross over events using ramps while still embracing its earlier beginnings in slalom, ditch skating, cornering, and just speed itself.{{citation needed|date=August 2014}}
==Records==
The land speed record on a longboard was set in 2017, when Peter Connolly reached a speed of 146.73 km/h (91.17 mph).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/fastest-skateboard-speed-standing |title=Fastest skateboard speed downhill (standing)|date=2017-09-16 |accessdate=2018-10-14}}</ref>
The marathon record is held by Paul Kent, who finished the 2011 [[Adrenalina Skateboard Marathon|Adrenalina Skateboard Marathon]] in Hallandale Beach, FL in 1:32:13. The women's record is held by Cami Best who skated a 2:01:07 at the 2011 Adrenalina in New York City.<ref>http://pavedwave.org</ref>
The record for distance skated in 24 hours is held by Rick Pronk, who skated 313 miles at the 2017 Dutch Ultraskate. The women's record is held by Saskia Tromp, who skated 262 miles, also at the 2017 Dutch Ultraskate.<ref>http://pavedwave.org/</ref>
A record for the longest distance traveled on a longboard was set by [[David Cornthwaite]] in 2006 when he skated {{convert|3638.26|mi|km}} from [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] to [[Brisbane]] across [[Australia]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ltd|first1=Allied Newspapers|title=British skateboarder sets record across Australia|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20070123/local/british-skateboarder-sets-record-across-australia.28727|accessdate=7 April 2016|work=Times of Malta|date=23 January 2007}}</ref> This record has since been broken by Rob Thomas of New Zealand, who skated {{convert|7555|mi|km}}.<ref>{{cite web|title=Longest journey by skateboard|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/longest-journey-by-skateboard/|website=[[Guinness World Records]]|accessdate=7 April 2016}}</ref>
==Uses==
===Transportation=== The most basic use of a longboard is travel. Commuter designs take many different shapes, including long, wide cruisers as well as shorter hybrid type boards. Their trucks are designed to be loose to allow for sharper turns. It is useful to have a [[kicktail]] on a commuting longboard in order to corner on sidewalks and to lift the front of the board when riding off [[curbs]].
Also, generally a shorter board, around 24"-35" is used for commuting, as well as medium-sized wheels (65mm-75mm) which help commuters maneuver bumps, cracks and other minor surface obstacles, perfect for students going to class on or off campus. For longer distances, a heavier (or longer) board and larger wheels will maintain the momentum from a push longer, making them ideal in that sense. One problem with this way of travel is that in some places it can be illegal. There have been cases when a longboarder has received a ticket for longboarding in certain areas, because some consider longboarding skateboarding.<ref>{{cite web|last=Dehaas|first=Josh|title='But it's not a skateboard': fans say it's eco-friendly, cops say it's risky. The fight over longboarding|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/retrieve.do?sgHitCountType=None&sort=DA-SORT&inPS=true&prodId=AONE&userGroupName=colosprings&tabID=T003&searchId=R28&resultListType=RESULT_LIST&contentSegment=&searchType=BasicSearchForm&currentPosition=3&contentSet=GALE%7CA239530034&&docId=GALE{{!}}A239530034&docType=GALE&role=|work=Article|publisher=Maclean's|accessdate=9 October 2012}}</ref>
===Freeride=== Freeriding can involve sliding and other tricks such as early grabs (where one grips the side of the board while on the ground and thrusts upward to become airborne) at medium to high speeds. The decks, which are often symmetrical, may have kicktails on both sides that allow for tech slides. These decks are typically from 36-44 inches long and from 8.5-10.5 inches wide. Most freeride decks utilize similar construction to downhill boards. Some companies are now trying to produce freeride decks that also do freestyle. They make these hybrid boards by adding kicktails and striving to make the boards out of lighter materials.
===Downhill=== [[File:Bo Peep 2012 19.jpg|thumb|Wet weather freeride downhill on a Landyachtz Evo longboard, Bo Peep hill, UK, 2012]] Downhill longboarding involves riding down hills as fast as possible and keeping the board under control. Speeds in excess of 80 mph have been obtained.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fastest skateboard speed, standing|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/1/fastest-skateboard-speed-standing|website=Guinness Book of World Records|accessdate=11 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Mischo Erban breaks Guinness World skateboard speed record – Again|url=http://www.longboardism.com/2012/06/mischo-erban-breaks-guinness-world-skateboard-speed-record.html|accessdate=10 August 2014|work=longboardism|date=June 2012}}</ref> UK rider, Pete Connolly, is the current Guinness world record holder, for the fastest man on a longboard, with a staggering top speed of 91.17 mph. These boards are usually 95–110 cm (35–44 inches) long, featuring wheel bases from 28-35 inches, and very stiff to improve control at speed. "Speed wobbles" pose a problem for beginner downhill riders but intermediate and advanced users overcome this by learning to relax and control their muscles. Downhill decks usually fall into Six categories: topmount, micro drop, drop thru, drop deck, double drop and flush mount. Topmount boards provide the most traction, but tend to be less forgiving. Micro Drops lower the ride height slightly, which results in a great all around board. Drop thru decks consist of mounting the baseplates of the trucks on top of the board with the trucks hanging through a hole. Like micro drops these tend to be all around boards and were very popular 2009-2011. Drop Decks get the rider very close to the ground, providing an easy to push and drifty ride. Double Drop decks are a drop deck with drop thru truck mounts. These decks were fairly popular in the mid 2000s but have largely fallen out of favor due to their unresponsiveness. Flush mounts seek to lower the ride height by mounting the trucks in a recessed area on the board. This minimally lowers ride height but increases the chance for wheel bite (which is where the wheels rub against the board in a turn, usually resulting in a crash). The vast majority of downhill long boards are built from wood. The three most common woods used are Maple, Baltic Birch and Bamboo. Maple is less prone to fracturing during construction than Baltic Birch, and as such is used in almost all high end boards. Other materials used in long board construction are: 1) Carbon fiber with a foam, balsa or hollow core. 2) Aluminum, either pressed or milled. And 3) Carbon Nano Tubes, although this proved prone to failure and no current company is using this material.
Downhill boards and freeride boards are often used interchangeably. The main distinguishing factor is that downhill boards are usually directional, with a defined front and rear, while freeride boards are symmetrical front to back.
Downhill longboarders usually use Reverse Kingpin Trucks (RKP), whereas skateboarders use Traditional Kingpin Trucks. RKP trucks tend to hold traction better and are easier to handle at speed, whereas TKP trucks are more suited for tricks, bowl skating and usually sport a lower ride height. Other forms of trucks have been seen in downhill but remain on the sidelines. These would include torsion trucks (seismic) and CAM trucks (Other Planet). Downhill trucks are separated into two further categories: Cast and Precision. Cast trucks are the economical choice as well as the most common, although Precision Trucks are becoming more common. Cast trucks are usually a gravity cast aluminum with a solid steel axle that is non-removable. Due to the casting process cast trucks have 'slop' which is caused by small gaps in between parts. This causes small shifts and movements at speed and results in slightly diminished control. Cast trucks are also prone to warping slightly, causing uneven contact pressure on the wheels. Precision trucks can counter these limitations at a much higher price tag, although not all brands achieve this equally. Precision trucks are milled out of Aluminum billet and usually house two separate axles.
The angle and width of trucks also come into play with most falling in the 35°-52° range. A 45° truck is the center point, providing an equal ratio of lean to turn while also providing the most overall turn. A higher degree truck initiates a turn faster with less lean, but reduces the overall turn of the system. This is useful for riders seeking to maximize traction. A lower angle truck initiates a turn slower with more lean, and this results in less overall turn. These trucks are useful for making sliding easier, and also for many beginners who are struggling with speed wobble. The most common widths used are 150-200mm, with 175mm and 180mm being the most common. Generally a narrower truck increases traction but is less forgiving. However this is directly related to the width of the board as the truck and the board work together to form a level against the bushing.
===Dancing===
Dancing is a resurgence of old-school tricks in longboarding that involves a variety of walking and spinning moves. Dancing originates from boardwalking in surfing. A board is usually considered a dancing board when it is around 45+ inches long and can be up to 12 inches wide, and although most of the tricks can be performed on smaller decks, a larger deck provides a more comfortable platform and takes less skill to maneuver.
=== Racing ===
====Downhill==== In downhill longboard racing there are two styles: luge and downhill. Luge is like downhill racing except the rider lays with their back on the board. Most people do downhill racing. In downhill racing the different courses are separated by difficulty. Each race is separated by gender and age. The race sections are Open, Women, Juniors, Masters, and Luge. Each race starts with four riders at the start line. A gun is fired to begin the race. After, the rider goes into a speed tuck. These tucks are used to make the body as aerodynamic as possible. This is done by having the rider lean over and bend their knees with their hands behind their back. The first rider to the bottom wins.<ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url=https://longboardingnation.com/introduction-into-the-world-of-longboard-racing/|title=Introduction into the World of Longboard Racing|last=|first=|date=|website=Longboarding Nation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
====Long Distance====
Long distance skateboard racing involves human-powered skating with propulsion from pushing, [[Pump (skateboarding)|pumping]], or both.
[https://theidsa.org/ The International Distance Skateboarding Association] is the governing body for the sport. The most popular forum for racers is [https://www.facebook.com/groups/429473203919081/ Distance Skateboarding Worldwide].
Some notable races include: * [https://24hourultraskate.com The 24-Hour Ultraskate] in Miami, FL * [http://www.dutchdistanceskaters.com/ultraskate/about/ The Dutch Ultraskate] * [[Adrenalina Skateboard Marathon|The Adrenalina Skateboard Marathon]] in San Diego, California * [[Broadway Bomb|The Broadway Bomb]] in New York, NY
=== Travel === {{main|Long distance pumping}} [[File:Globe_Front_Clear_Grip_Tape_Bamboo_SIDE.JPG|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Globe_Front_Clear_Grip_Tape_Bamboo_SIDE.JPG|thumb|Drop-through longboard deck]] Longboards can be used for traveling long distances. Long distance skating with charitable fundraising has even emerged (see [[Charitable distance skating]]). Any skateboard can be used for long distance journeys, however, decks designed specifically for long distance trips are typically lower to the ground than regular top mounted longboards. Common ways to lower the decks are in the construction of the boards; drop-through mounting<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.windwardboardshop.com/learn/understanding-longboard-decks/|title=Understanding Longboard Decks|author=Tony|date=1 October 2015|website=Windward Boardshop}}</ref> allows for the whole board to be mounted lower on the trucks and can be combined with a drop-down deck. Drop-down decks are shaped to allow the riders feet to ride lower than where the trucks are mounted. A lower deck increases stability and makes for easy pushing and foot braking.
=== Slalom === Slaloming is the act of weaving in and out of a line of obstacles. Riders often compete for the fastest time through the course.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://longboardguide.wordpress.com/styles/slalom/|title=Longboarding|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Pedestrian slalom (usually referred to as civilian slalom because of the alliteration) is a non-competitive form of this discipline in which riders simply swerve around whatever obstacles they find in their path while navigating from point A to B.
=== Electric Longboarding === {{see also|Electric skateboard}} The electric longboard is a variant of the original longboard and a new way of transport. It is essentially a longboard with a motor connected, usually to the rear wheels, and can be used to travel longer distances.
== Riding Techniques ==
=== Sliding (riding) === {{See also|Slides (skateboarding)}} In addition to its role as a braking technique, sliding has evolved into its own discipline within skateboarding, with riders performing various tricks and rotations while sliding. Specific slides include the coleman slide, bert slide, and pendulum. Sliding can be performed on any wheel. Harder wheels (83-86a) will slide less smoothly and break traction easier while softer wheels (70-80a) will be harder to break traction but will lead to a smoother more controllable slide. Softer wheels, especially (70-75a), tend to wear out faster. Slides can be done standing upright or with one or two hands placed on the road to allow the rider to execute technical slides in any number of positions. When performing hands-down slides, protective slide gloves must be worn. These gloves can be purchased or made at home. They are usually leather gloves with sliding pucks made of hard, low-friction plastics such as [[Ultra-high-molecular-weight polyethylene|UHMWPE]], Corian, or Delrin attached by velcro or glue. Sliding gloves can also be bought online or at local skate shops. Gloves are commonly made by companies such as Sector 9, Vault, Landyachtz, Arbor and Loaded. Slides can also be performed on banks and transitions in a skate park. When a skater slides to a complete stop, it is called a shutdown slide. A drift that reduces the rider's speed without bringing him to a complete stop is called a speed check. Riders will also do a partial slide called a pre-drift before a corner to trim speed and then hook back up and grip the corner. When the board rotates more than 90 degrees and then returns to its original position over the course of the slide it is called a pendulum. There are myriad more technical and challenging slides that can be done such as laybacks, pressure spins, 5-0 slides, and stand-up rotations. One of the most popular slide and most basic hands-down slide is called the Coleman. Made popular by Cliff Coleman, the Coleman slide is the most popular slide used to come to a complete stop, as the rider does a complete 180 degree turn with one hand on the ground.
=== Carving === Carving is an effective way to control speed when traveling downhill. Instead of coming to a complete stop, the rider makes a continuous "S" path by leaning left and right. By making many turns speed can be controlled and maintained.
Boards with camber are specifically designed for carving. A camber board is usually made of a flexible wood like bamboo, and the center of the deck will be higher than the mounting point of the trucks creating an arc shape. When weight is applied the center will bend down, creating a reverse of the arc shape. This builds spring tension, that is released at the peak of every complete turn in the "S" pattern.
=== Pumping === Pumping a skateboard is a technique used and perfected in slalom skateboarding<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://longboardguide.wordpress.com/styles/slalom/|title=Longboard|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. It is a technique used to maintain speed without the rider taking his or her feet off of the skateboard. The motion itself is somewhat unorthodox and it requires the rider to be very in sync with his or her center of gravity and skateboard. The act of pumping a longboard is the bending of ones knees in the direction of a turn to compensate for the gravitational forces in order to maintain speed. Boards made specifically for pumping usually consist of large longboard wheels which range anywhere from 60mm to 80mm. These wheels are normally soft to promote grip and have rebound urethane to maintain the resilience of the wheel. The trucks on the skateboard are also essential to how it will pump. Bennett Vectors are a very popular pumping truck and when mixed with the right durometer (measure of hardness) bushings experienced boarders can travel long distances without touching a foot to the ground. In a skateboarding world full of kick flips and 900's, pumping had become virtually extinct. Now it is beginning to make a revival with the popularity of alternative transportation and longboard distance skating.
=== Early grabs === Early grabbing is a technique of achieving height that originated in old school skateboarding, in which the rider grabs the board and lifts it while initiating a jumping motion. The most common technique of doing this is by placing the right hand (for goofy riders) or left hand (for regular riders) on the backside of the board between the legs, for this tends to be the technique that gives the body the least resistance when jumping/lifting. Although this has become semi-obsolete due to freeriding alternatives with kicktails which have the ability to ollie (ex. Loaded Chubby Unicorn, Omen Sugar, DK penguin), it is commonly practiced on decks that lack tails (ex. Landyachtz 9 two 5, Comet Grease Shark, Earthwing Supermodel) and can be used to navigate the environment more easily (over ledges, off ledges, and off kickers).
=== Cross Step === One of the most important core tricks for longboard dancing. Cross steps involve moving the rider's back foot around the front, flipping the front around the back, and moving into a switched position from the rider's natural stance. Carve during this trick for extra style by crossing closer to the edge. Cross steps can be used to change positions with style and flow to the riders cruising.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.concretecoast.com/blogs/longboarding/ultimate-guide-to-longboard-dancing|title=Ultimate Guide to Longboard Dancing|website=Concrete Coast|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref>
=== Land Paddling === [[File:Land_Paddling.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Land_Paddling.jpg|thumb|Land paddling.]] Land Paddling is the use of a long pole or stick while longboarding. The stick is used to propel the longboarder further without pumping. The stick also maintains balance and can be used as a brake. This variation was stated to be an invention by Steve McBride of Kahuna Creations,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vogue.com/vogue-daily/article/vd-land-paddling-is-coming-to-a-bicycle-lane-near-you/|title=Land Paddling is Coming to a Bicycle Lane Near You|last=Goodman|first=Liam|work=Vogue|publisher=Vogue|accessdate=30 June 2009}}</ref> but this method of pushing has been around longer and can't be claimed by a single person.
=== Train === A train involves a group of riders riding in a straight line down a hill. The front rider [[Drafting (aerodynamics)|drafts]] for the following riders, who in turn use their hands to push the front rider through the wind for increased overall speed for the entire group. This technique requires skill and practice because riders are in such close proximity. [[File:Maryhill_Fall_Freeride_2012-_spaghettii_corners_3.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Maryhill_Fall_Freeride_2012-_spaghettii_corners_3.jpg|thumb|Downhill pack riding at Maryhill, Washington]]
=== Drafting === {{main|Drafting (aerodynamics)}} Drafting is used by downhill riders to increase speed and pass other riders. It involves riding directly behind another rider to take advantage of the rider in front breaking the wind. A successful draft can greatly increase speed. The drafting rider waits until the last second to break from out behind the front rider to maximize the speed gained.
=== Tucks ===
==== American ==== In downhill, an American tuck involves the rider tucking his/her back knee right behind his/her front knee and leaning onto his/her front thigh. Many find this tuck to be one of the most comfortable to hold while providing for a very flat, aerodynamic back with a small frontal profile. This tuck results in larger draft pocket behind the rider, which is used in a race to pass.
==== Euro ==== A Euro tuck involves the rider tucking his/her back knee right behind his/her front ankle and leaning onto his/her front thigh. This tuck gets the rider very low, but many find it to be uncomfortable and it creates a larger frontal profile which creates drag. It does reduce the draft pocket by guiding the air downwards due to the curved back.
==== Hybrid ==== A Hybrid tuck involves the rider tucking his/her back knee into the middle of his/her front calf. This tuck provides a balance between the Euro and American, taking some of the advantages and disadvantages of each.
==== Brazilian ==== A Brazilian tuck consists of the rider placing his/her back knee directly onto the board next to or behind the front foot. This Tuck has largely fallen out of favor for competitive riding. This is because it creates a very large frontal section that dramatically increases aerodynamic drag. It's mostly used by beginners or as a resting position for some people during very long runs.
==== Classic ==== A classic Tuck is one that was primarily used in the 1980s and 1990s. However some modern events, such as the MT Tabor Challenge in Portland Oregon, require this tuck to increase the difficulty on mellow hills. The tuck involves placing both feet at the front of the board, touching with one foot slightly behind the other. The rider then crouches down somewhat similar to a modern tuck. This tuck provides a severely reduced amount of control due to the rider having minimal control over the rear trucks. Further the stance has higher aerodynamic drag than other tucks.
== Braking Techniques ==
Because of the high speed a longboard can achieve (as fast as a car), being able to brake quickly is extremely important.
=== Run out === While not an official braking technique, it is common for riders to jump off the moving board and 'run out' their speed. This is safe only at low speeds. This technique is considered dangerous and is least accepted in the longboarding community. If the rider is traveling faster than the speed at which they can run, other techniques are required, for example footbraking or sliding.<ref name=":0" />
=== Sliding (braking) === Sliding is the most effective braking technique for downhill skateboarders. Sliding is the method of pushing the edge of the board out so it is traveling sideways rather than forwards, and the wheels are sliding against the ground. The resulting friction slows the board down dramatically. It allows a skater to reduce his or her speed much quicker than footbraking, but requires a wider area depending on their ability to control the slide. Factors such as the height and length of the board and, crucially, durometer (softness) of the wheels affect how easy this is to do and how fast the rider must be travelling to achieve effective slides. Sliding also requires an efficient and precise use of body weight in order to be fully effective.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|title=Longboarding essentials|url=http://www.tactics.com/info/longboarding|website=Tactics|accessdate=11 August 2014}}</ref>
===Foot Braking=== [[File:Longboarding along the Columbia River East Wenatchee Washington.jpg|thumb|Footbraking Technique]] Foot braking involves putting one foot on the road while balancing on the board with the other foot. The rider needs to put all of their weight on their front foot. This technique can be used to reduce speed or come to a full stop and it is a very helpful technique for an emergency case.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.skateboardlab.com/how-to-stop-a-longboard/|title=How to stop a Longboard - Skateboard Lab|website=Skateboard Lab|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-11}}</ref> This is helpful in racing or in tight situations where the rider does not feel comfortable sliding, or when a rider only needs to lose a small amount of speed prior to entering a turn. However this method can be wasteful and tends to destroy shoes as the sole of the shoe is worn away and doesn't shed speed nearly as fast as sliding.
==== Frog braking ==== A much less common form of foot braking is frog braking. This is where the rider grabs rail on both sides of the board and then stomps a foot down while crouched. This method allows the rider to shed speed much faster than a normal foot brake due the rider being able to apply much greater pressure against the road. This method still does not slow the rider down as much as a slide and is considered 'odd' by most riders.
==== Sit braking ==== Another variation of foot braking is a sit braking. This involves the rider going from a standing position to sitting on the board and putting both feet down. This method can slow the rider down very quickly. The downside to this method is that it takes some time to sit down on the board. This is usually used at the end of a run.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tactics.com/info/longboarding|title=Longboarding Essentials|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Air brake === Air braking involves standing upright on the board as tall as possible with arms outstretched to catch as much wind resistance as possible. In racing this is done by standing up from the rider's tuck. This is primarily done in speedboarding to reduce speed before a tight turn. It is not meant to stop the rider, but rather slow the rider to maintain control and stability. The effect is most noticeable at higher speeds and can be enhanced by deploying a [[Sporting-Sails|Sporting-Sail]], jacket or other article of clothing, forming a parachute.
==Safety== Longboarding is associated with a different pattern of injuries than skateboarding is. Many longboarding injuries are sustained while going downhill, while very few skateboarding accidents happen while going downhill. In downhill racing the riders are required to wear certain protective gear unlike other uses of the longboard where a helmet and padding may be worn. Full closed helmet, pads on the rider's elbows, knees, and wrist, gloves, slide pucks, and a leather suit are required. This equipment is mandated by the International Downhill Federation.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://longboardingnation.com/introduction-into-the-world-of-longboard-racing/|title=Introduction into the World of Longboard Racing|last=|first=|date=|website=Longboarding Nation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Longboarding injuries tend to involve head and neck areas more than skateboarding injuries, which are more likely to involve a skater's lower extremities.<ref name=keays>{{cite journal|last1=Keays|first1=Glenn|last2=Dumas|first2=Alex|title=Longboard and skateboard injuries|journal=Injury|volume=45|issue=8|pages=1215–1219|doi=10.1016/j.injury.2014.03.010}}</ref> Helmets, padding, and possibly friendly or parental supervision are highly recommended or enforced by law.
Scholars Glenn Keays and Alex Dumas found media reports of five longboard-related deaths in Canada and the United States during 2012, and four in 2013.<ref name="keays" /> A number of municipalities—most notably [[Vancouver]]—have considered banning or restricting longboarding, expressing concern with the speeds longboarders can reach.<ref>{{cite news|title=Should longboarding be banned on public streets?|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/should-longboarding-be-banned-on-public-streets-1.1403855|accessdate=10 August 2014|work=CBC News|date=12 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Shepherd|first1=Jeremy|title=Longboarders given a break on North Shore but could face future ban|url=http://www.theprovince.com/travel/2012+Longboarders+given+break+North+Shore+could+face+future/8377377/story.html|accessdate=10 August 2014|work=The Province|date=1 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Concerns Growing Over Longboarding Safety In Dallas|url=http://www.polkio.com/news/2013/jun/24/concerns-growing-over-longboarding-safety-in/|accessdate=10 August 2014|work=Polk County Itemizer-Observer|date=24 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Payne|first1=Sarah|title=Coquitlam aims to ban longboarding|url=http://www.tricitynews.com/news/266667201.html|accessdate=10 August 2014|work=Tri-City News|date=10 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Warnica|first1=Richard|title=Freedom to ride?|journal=Maclean's|date=2 April 2014|volume=125|issue=12|page=24}}</ref>

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = Paysandú | image = [[Image:Paysandu FC.png|100px]]| fullname = Paysandú Fútbol Club| nickname = Sanduceros | founded = March 7, 2003| | ground = [[Estadio Parque Artigas]]
[[Paysandú]], [[Uruguay]]| capacity = 25,000 | chairman = Hector Lancieri | manager = Juan Silvera | league = Disaffiliated | season = 2006/07| position = [[Segunda División Uruguay]], withdrew| pattern_la1=_bluelower|pattern_b1=_redhorizontal|pattern_ra1=_bluelower| leftarm1=ffffff|body1=ffffff|rightarm1=ffffff|shorts1=ffffff|socks1=ffffff| pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=_bluestripes|pattern_ra2=| leftarm2=0000ff|body2=ff0000|rightarm2=0000ff|shorts2=0000ff|socks2=ff0000| }} '''Paysandú Fútbol Club''' are a [[football (soccer)|football]] club from [[Paysandú]] in [[Uruguay]]. They were formed in 2003, making them one of the youngest football clubs in Uruguay. They were formed by the amalgamation of several local clubs: Barrio Obrero, Centenario, Deportivo América, Estudentil, Independiente, Juventud Unida, Olimpico and Paysandú Wanderers. This new club played in the 2005/2006 [[Primera División Uruguaya]], but were relegated back to the 2nd level after finishing bottom of the table. {{DEFAULTSORT:Paysandu F.C.}} [[Category:Football clubs in Uruguay]] [[Category:Sport in Paysandú]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 2003]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Uruguay]] {{Uruguay-footyclub-stub}}

{{For|places with similar names|Ponce de León (disambiguation)#Places}} {{Infobox venue |stadium_name=Ponce de Leon Park |image=Ponce de Leon Park.JPG |caption=Night game at Ponce de Leon Park |image_size=200px |nickname=Poncey |location=[[Atlanta, Georgia]] |coordinates= |broke_ground=1907 | opened = May 23, 1907 |owner=Georgia Railway and Electric |surface=Grass | construction_cost = $60,000 |seating_capacity=6,800 }}
'''Ponce de Leon Park''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|p|ɒ|n|s|_|d|ə|_|ˈ|l|iː|ən}} {{respell|PONSS|_|də|_|LEE|ən}}; also known as '''Spiller Park''' or '''Spiller Field''' from 1924 to 1932, and "'''Poncey'''" to locals, was the primary home field for the [[minor league baseball]] team called the [[Atlanta Crackers]] for nearly six decades. The Crackers played here in the [[Southern Association]] (1907–1959) and the [[International League]] (1962–64). It was also home of the [[Atlanta Black Crackers]] who captured the second half championship of the Negro American League in 1938.<ref>[http://www.nlbpa.com/atlanta_black_crackers.html NLBPA] Atlanta Black Crackers</ref>
The ballpark was located at 650 [[Ponce de Leon Avenue]]; the street ran along the south side of the park i.e. along its [[First baseman|first base]] side. Behind right and center field, atop the slope bordering the park on the East, were the tracks of the [[Southern Railway (US)|Southern Railway]], now part of the [[BeltLine]], a trail and future transit ring around the central neighborhoods of Atlanta. Across the street was the [[Ponce de Leon Amusement Park]] until 1926, when the hulking [[Sears Roebuck]] Southeastern Headquarters, now known as [[Ponce City Market]], was built.
The original ballpark on the site opened in 1907. The structure was destroyed by fire in 1923. It was rebuilt in 1924 and was named for club owner Rell J. Spiller. It reverted to its original name in 1933. The seating capacity of the park was about 20,000.
[[Image:Ponce de Leon Park magnolia tree.jpg|thumb|right|Magnolia tree at shopping center]] The park was known for a [[magnolia tree]] in deep center field. Balls landing in the tree remained in play, until [[Earl Mann]] took over the team in 1947 and had the outfield wall moved in about 50 feet.<ref>[http://www.ajc.com/living/content/living/0403/25tree.html Tree stands as link to city's baseball roots], an April 25, 2003 article from ''[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]''</ref> During exhibition games, [[Babe Ruth]] and [[Eddie Mathews]] both hit home runs that became stuck in the distant tree.{{citation needed|date=June 2012}}
After the Crackers moved to [[Atlanta Stadium]] in 1965, Ponce de Leon Park was demolished in favor of a shopping center (now also demolished) and today a strip mall, Midtown Place, occupies the location. The famous magnolia tree is still standing at the rear of the shopping center along the BeltLine trail.
==College football== [[College football]] games were also once hosted at Ponce de Leon Park. The [[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football|Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets]] played all their home games there from 1908 to 1911. The [[Georgia Bulldogs football|Georgia Bulldogs]] have also played games at 'Poncey.'
==Other events== On July 1, 1940, the park hosted an exhibition fight<ref>[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1006463/2/index.htm Aging Bull - Jack Dempsey's 1940 'comeback' was a sad and mercifully short spectacle], an April 17, 1995 article from ''[[Sports Illustrated]]''</ref> between a 45-year-old [[Jack Dempsey]] and wrestler Clarence (Cowboy) Luttrell which Dempsey won.
The park also hosted regular Friday night high school football games between [[Henry W. Grady High School|Tech High]] Smithies and Boys' High Purple Hurricanes during the 1940s which sometimes outdrew the college games.<ref name="gaTrend">{{cite web | url=http://www.georgiatrend.com/features-sports-leisure/ray-chaney.shtml | title=The Ultimate Rivalry | work=Georgia Trend | date=July 2006 | accessdate=June 20, 2012 | author=Asher, Gene}}</ref>
==References== <references /> *''Ballparks of North America'', by Michael Benson, McFarland Press, 1989. *''Ernie Harwell's Audio Scrapbook'', by [[Ernie Harwell]] and [[Bob Harris (sportscaster)|Bob Harris]], AudioBook Publications, 2006. *Darnell, Tim. "Ponce de Leon Ballpark." New Georgia Encyclopedia. 5 April 2016. Web. 6 May 2016.
==External links== *[http://album.atlantahistorycenter.com/store/Advanced_Search.aspx?c=449&t=Clarence July 1, 1940-Dempsey v Luttrell photo gallery] [[Atlanta History Center]] *[http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/Article.jsp?path=/SportsRecreation/IndividualandTeamSports/Baseball&id=h-2475 Georgia Encyclopedia] *Sarah Toton, "[https://web.archive.org/web/20110717085827/http://southernspaces.org/2008/vale-amusements-modernity-technology-and-atlantas-ponce-de-leon-park-1870-1920 Vale of Amusements: Modernity, Technology, and Atlanta's Ponce de Leon Park, 1870-1920]" ''Southern Spaces'', 15 January 2008. https://web.archive.org/web/20110717085827/http://southernspaces.org/2008/vale-amusements-modernity-technology-and-atlantas-ponce-de-leon-park-1870-1920

revision.text:
The '''South African Rugby Football Federation''' was an association formed by the majority of "[[Coloured]]" rugby union clubs that broke away from the South African Coloured Rugby Football Board (SACRFB) in the 1960s to affiliate with the whites-only [[South African Rugby Board]] (SARB).<ref name=Nation>{{cite book | last1 = Black | first1 = David Ross | last2 = Nauright | first2 = John | title = Rugby and the South African Nation | publisher = Manchester University Press | year = 1998 | location = Manchester, UK | accessdate = 2011-12-20}}</ref> The SACRFB was founded in 1896.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.rugbyfootballhistory.com/south_africa.html | title = The History of South African Rugby | accessdate = 2011-12-20 | publisher = RugbyFootballHistory.com }}</ref>
The split with the SACRFB was driven by a number of factors and people, including [[personality clashes]] between SACRFB rugby officials Cuthbert Loriston and Abdullah Abbass.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Magdalinski | first1 = Tara | last2 = Chandler | first2 = Timothy John | title = With God on Their Side: Sport in the Service of Religion | publisher = Routledge | year = 2002 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=vM_KHo1aiHcC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false | accessdate = 2011-12-29}}</ref> Since the 1950s black, [[coloured]] and Indian sporting codes had come under increased pressure to pursue three divergent paths: form non-racial organisations, affiliate with white associations (where they would continue within their segregated leagues), or refuse to do either. From the 1960s the formation of organisations such as the [[South African Sports Association]] and the [[South African Non-Racial Olympic Committee]] pressurised black sports groupings to move towards non-racial amalgamation.<ref name=Nation /> [[Danie Craven]], then president of SARB, was one of the main driving forces behind the drive to affiliate coloured rugby under the SARB, believing that he could not desegregate rugby unilaterally while all other sporting codes followed the segregation policies set by the [[apartheid]] government.<ref name=Nation />
Loriston became the first president of the newly constituted SARFF, while the remainder of the SACRFB's clubs formed the SACOS-affiliated [[South African Rugby Union (SACOS)|South African Rugby Union]] under leadership of Abass. SARU promoted non-racial rugby instead of the racially segregated associations that existed under SARB's organisational umbrella.<ref name=Nation /> It should not be confused with the body founded in 1992 that presently governs rugby in South Africa.
==See also== * [[Proteas (rugby union)|Proteas]] * [[South African African Rugby Board]] * [[South African Rugby Union]] * [[South African Rugby Union (SACOS)]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Rugby union governing bodies in South Africa|Rugby]] [[Category:Rugby union and apartheid]]

{{Infobox horseraces | class = Discontinued stakes | horse race = Spindrift Stakes | image = | caption = | location = [[Aqueduct Racetrack]]
[[Queens|Queens, New York]], [[United States]] | inaugurated = 1886 | race type = [[Thoroughbred]] - [[Flat racing]] | website = | distance = {{frac|1|1|8}} miles (9 furlongs) | surface = Dirt | track = Left-handed | qualification = Three-year-olds | weight = Assigned | purse = | bonuses = }} The '''Spindrift Stakes''' was an American [[Thoroughbred horse race]] run annually between 1886 and 1909 at [[Sheepshead Bay Race Track]] at [[Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. A race for three-year-olds, it was contested on dirt over a distance of {{frac|1|1|4}} miles (10 [[furlong]]s) from 1886–1892 and at {{frac|1|1|8}} miles (9 furlongs) from 1893 through 1909. The race ended with the closure of the Coney Island Jockey Club's racetrack, brought on by the [[New York Legislature|State legislature's]] enactment of the [[Hart-Agnew Law]]. ==Records== '''Speed record:''' * 1:51.80 - Fashion Plate (1909) (at {{frac|1|1|8}} miles) * 2:09.40 - Sir John (1890) (at {{frac|1|1|4}} miles) '''Most wins by a [[jockey]]:''' * 2 - [[Henry Spencer (jockey)|Henry Spencer]] (1899, 1900) '''Most wins by a [[Horse trainer|trainer]]:''' * 4 - [[James G. Rowe, Sr.]] (1888, 1903, 1906, 1907) '''Most wins by an owner:''' * 2 - [[Dwyer Brothers Stable]] (1887, 1890) * 2 - [[Samuel S. Brown]] & [[John W. Rogers (racehorse trainer)|John W. revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox recurring event | name = Superhero Scramble | native_name = | logo = | logo_caption = The Superhero Scramble Logo | image = | imagesize = | caption = | date = | begins = | ends = | frequency = | location = United States | years_active = | first = 2011 | last = July 28, 2012 | participants = | genre = Obstacle Race | budget = | patron = | website = {{url|superheroscramble.com}} | footnotes = }} [[File:The SUPER Slime Slide.jpg|thumb|239px|A participant exiting the ''Super Slime Slide'']] [[File:The Leap of Faith.jpg|thumb|239px|A participant flips off of the ''Leap of Faith'' jump]] '''Superhero Scramble''' was a superhero themed [[obstacle race]] series that has several levels of races.{{cite book|author=James Villepigue|title=Obstacle Race Training Bible: The #1 Resource to Prepare for and Conquer Any Course!|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Dgf0B2D86MUC&pg=PA34|date=4 December 2012|publisher=DK Publishing|isbn=978-1-101-59832-0|pages=281–}}[http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/amputees-tackle-superhero-scramble-article-1.1403534 "].''New York Daily News'', Rheana Murray, July 19, 2013 The majority of participants participate for fun, while others compete for team and individual prize money that's available at each event.[http://www.gainesville.com/article/20120728/ARTICLES/120729604 "Superhero Scramble adds fun to fitness"]. ''Gainesville Sun''. Participants frequently dress in costumes based on characters from video games, movies, cartoons, and comic books. The all-day events included live bands, DJ's, emcees, entertainers, food and beer. There were also night races and kids races. == History == The Superhero Scramble was founded in June, 2011, in Boca Raton, Florida by Sean O'Connor.[http://www.racked.com/2014/8/21/7580483/tough-mudder-spartan-race-warrior-dash-mudderella-mud-run "The Messy, Rapid Rise of Obstacle Course Racing"]. ''Racked'', Chavie Lieber Aug 21, 2014 The first event occurred on November 12, 2011 at Quiet Waters Park in Deerfield Beach, and attracted nearly 2000 people. Three more events took place in Florida during the next twelve months, and subsequently the group has organized national leve events across the US.{{cite web|last=Chiang|first=Anthony|title=No obstacle too big for father-daughter in Superhero Scramble|date=January 10, 2013|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2013-01-10/sports/fl-superhero-scramble-woodall-0111-20130110_1_father-daughter-race-andy|publisher=Sun Sentinel|accessdate=10 January 2013}} Men and women participate about equally in the races, and both young and older adults take part. After 2013, the Superhero Scramble, as well as several other obstacle races, had some financial trouble because fewer people were signing up to participate.{{cite book|author=Erin Beresini|title=Off Course: Inside the Mad, Muddy World of Obstacle Course Racing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dLXaAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA217|date=14 October 2014|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|isbn=978-0-544-05552-0|pages=217–}} == Course == Superhero Scramble race courses vary in distance and difficulty from four mile "Charger" courses, to eight mile "Intimidator" courses, as well as thirteen mile (half marathon) "Villain" and the 26 mile (marathon) "Super Villain." Projected finishing times for the events range from 30 minutes to 12 hours, depending on the particular course and fitness level of the racer. Race venues have included ski slopes, state parks, paint ball parks, off-road parks, and more. Any competitor who completes all three race distances within a 12-month period is eligible to receive special designation as a "Superhero Legend." == Obstacles == The Superhero Scramble races include a variety of obstacles including the ''Leap of Faith'' jump, ''The Beast'' climbing wall, the ''Spiderweb'' ropes course, the ''Real'' Barbed Wire, the ''Top of the World'' Container Crossing, the ''Dumpster Divin'' ice bath, the ''Super Slime Slide'' and several mud slides.[http://www.cnn.com/2015/01/25/travel/coolest-themed-runs/ "11 of the world's coolest themed runs"]. By Tamara Hinson, for ''CNN'', February 3, 2015[http://archive.defense.gov/homepagephotos/leadphotoimage.aspx?id=79025 "SUPERHERO SCRAMBLE"]. United States Department of Defense website, Scott Schmidt === Scramble Gamble === The ''Scramble Gamble'' allows participants to win a cash prize whereby half the entrance fees are given to charity and the remaining half split between the top 3 finishers. == Charitable Partnership == Superhero Scramble supports Forgotten Soldiers Outreach (FSO),[http://www.forgottensoldiers.org/ "Forgotten Soldiers Outreach"] which was founded in 2003 to send monthly "We Care" packages to U.S. servicemen and servicewomen abroad. To date, FSO has benefited over 250,000 military personnel serving abroad, covering ALL world theaters. == Night Waves == In July, 2012 in Waldo, Fl,[http://www.gainesville.com/article/20120728/ARTICLES/120729604?tc=ar "Superhero Scramble Adds Fun to Fitness"] The Gainesville Sun, July 28, 2012 Superhero Scramble held its first night waves. Races where participants ran the same course that was set up during the day, navigating by way of the moonlight and their headlamps.[http://www.mudrunfun.com/reviews/superhero-scramble/ "Superhero Scramble Reviews"] Mud Run Fun == Super Kids Race == Kids can run their own version of the Superhero Scramble. The course is estimated to be 1 mile long and with 5 or more obstacles. Age groups of 4-8 and 9-13 run together. Parents are encouraged to run with their children. Participants receive a medal, a sticker and a temporary tattoo. == Past events ==
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" ! Date !! Location !! City |- !colspan=3|2011 |- |November 2, 2011 || [[Quiet Waters Park]]|| Deerfield Beach, FL[http://www.multisportlifestyle.com/adventure-annas-races/2011/11/12/superhero-scramble.html"Adventure Anna's Races"] Multi Sport Lifestyle |- !colspan=3|2012 |- | March 12, 2012 || [[Oleta River State Park]]|| Miami, FL |- | July 28, 2012 || Waldo Motorsports Park || Waldo, FL |- !colspan=3|2013 |- | January 12, 2013 || Emilia Earhart State Park|| Miami, FL |- | April 27, 2013 || Redwine’s Cove – The Medusa|| Dalton, GA |- | June, 2013 || Amesbury Sports Park[http://www.bostonherald.com/photos/superhero_scramble "Superhero Scramble"]. ''Boston Herald'', Patrick Whittemore June 09, 2013 || Amesbury, MA |- | August, 2013 || Tuxedo Ridge Ski Center|| Tuxedo, NY |}

{{Infobox athletic conference | name = Tampa Bay Christian Athletic League | short_name = TBCAL | established = | dissolved = | logo = | logo_size = | association = | division = | subdivision = | members = | sports = | mens = | womens = | region = | former_names = Brandon Christian Athletic League (BCAL) | hq_city = Tampa | hq_state = Florida | commissioner = | since = | website = http://www.hometeamsonline.com | color = | font_color = | map = | map_size = }}
The '''Tampa Bay Christian Athletic League''' is an association of private schools in [[Hillsborough County, Florida]], originally formed as the Brandon Christian Athletic League for the purpose of providing intermural athletics to a number of schools.
== Current members ==
Current members include:
*[[Www.bsbacademy.com|Bell Shoals Baptist Academy]] *Central Baptist Christian School <ref>http://www.cbcslions.com/home/aboutus/athletics</ref> *Faith Christian Academy *Family of Christ Knights <ref>http://focathletics.org/tbcal/</ref> *F.I.S.H.<ref>http://bellshoals.com/other-ministries/fish/</ref> *[[Florida College Academy]] Falcons *Immanuel Lutheran School <ref>http://www.ilsbrandon.com/athletics/</ref> *New Jerusalem *[[Tampa Bay HEAT]] <ref>https://www.homeschool-life.com/1883/custom/31787</ref><ref name=Ceballos>{{cite news|last1=Ceballos|first1=John|title=Homeschooled athletes turn up the HEAT on the competition|url=http://www.tbo.com/brandon/homeschooled-athletes-turn-up-the-heat-on-the-competition-562606|date=14 November 2012}}</ref>
==Former members==
Former members include [[Foundation Christian Academy]], [[Seffner Christian Academy]], and Brandon Academy.
==References==
{{reflist|refs=http://www.bsbacademy.com}}

Ana Lucía Migliarini de León (8) }} The '''Uruguay Fed Cup team''' represents [[Uruguay]] in [[Fed Cup]] [[tennis]] competition and are governed by the [[Asociación Uruguaya de Tenis]]. They currently compete in the Americas Zone Group II. ==History== Uruguay competed in its first Fed Cup in [[1972 Federation Cup (tennis)|1972]]. Their best result was reaching the round of 16 in [[1972 Federation Cup (tennis)|1972]] and [[1976 Federation Cup (tennis)|1976]]. ==See also== *[[Fed Cup]] *[[Uruguay Davis Cup team]] ==External links== *{{FedCupteamlink|code=URU}} {{Fed Cup}} [[Category:Fed Cup teams]] [[Category:Tennis in Uruguay|Fed Cup]] [[Category:National sports teams of Uruguay|Fed Cup]] {{FedCup-stub}} {{Uruguay-sport-stub}}

'''Utalii Football Club''' was a football club from [[Ruaraka]], upported by the [[Utalii College]], which specialised in cooking, tourism and hotel management. It won the [[Kenya Premier League]] title in 1997. However, due to mismanagement at its parent college, it became impossible to find resources to keep the club running and it as wound up. It was dissolved in 2005.
==Honours== *[[FKF President's Cup]]: 2003

{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Yurtec Stadium Sendai | nick_name = | image = [[Image:Sendaistadium2.JPG|250px]]| | publictransit = '''[[Sendai Subway]]''':
[[Sendai Subway Namboku Line|Namboku Line]] at [[Izumi-Chūō Station (Miyagi)|Izumi-Chūō]] | location = {{flagicon|Japan}} [[Sendai]], [[Japan]] | coordinates = {{coord|38|19|9|N|140|52|55|E|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = | opened = June 1997 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Sendai City | operator = Sendai City Park Association | surface = Grass | Constructor = | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = '''Sendai Stadium''' (1997-2006) | nicknames = | tenants = [[Vegalta Sendai]] ([[J. League]])
[[Sony Sendai F.C.]] ([[Japan Football League|JFL]]) | seating_capacity = 19,694 | dimensions = 139 x 79 m }} {{nihongo|'''Yurtec Stadium Sendai'''|ユアテックスタジアム仙台}} is a [[football (soccer)|football]] stadium in the Nanakita Park, Izumi-ku, [[Sendai|Sendai City]], [[Miyagi Prefecture]], [[Japan]]. It was built in 1997 and is home to the [[J. League]] club [[Vegalta Sendai]] and the [[Japan Football League]] club [[Sony Sendai F.C.]]. The stadium was specifically designed for football, and the stands are arranged close to the pitch. For games where the spectator capacity is insufficient, nearby [[Miyagi Stadium]] is occasionally used as a substitute. ==History== The naming rights for the stadium were sold beginning on March 1, 2006 until February 28, 2009. In that period, the stadium is officially known as {{Nihongo|''Yurtec STADIUM SENDAI''|ユアテックスタジアム仙台|Yuatekku Sutajiamu Sendai}}. In 2009, the turf were replaced, and Vegalta played the first half of the season at Miyagi Stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.kahoku.co.jp/spe/spe106/news_spe/news20080408_001.htm |script-title=ja:仙台―広島戦宮スタが会場 |publisher=河北新報 |date=2008-04-08 |language=Japanese |accessdate=2008-04-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080412061410/http://www.kahoku.co.jp/spe/spe106/news_spe/news20080408_001.htm |archivedate=April 12, 2008 }} The stadium was damaged after the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]].{{cite news |title=Japan cancels all March games in top soccer league |author= |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110314/ap_on_sp_so_ne/soc_earthquake_soccer_suspension;_ylt=Ak8A6VqFUi6zDeHDN9RZTroLMxIF;_ylu=X3oDMTMxYXFyMHVnBGFzc2V0A2FwLzIwMTEwMzE0L3NvY19lYXJ0aHF1YWtlX3NvY2Nlcl9zdXNwZW5zaW9uBGNwb3MDMwRwb3MDNQRzZWMDeW5fdG9wX3N0b3J5BHNsawNqYXBhbmNhbmNlbHM- |newspaper=Yahoo! Sports |date=2011-03-14|accessdate=2011-03-14}} ==International matches== ===Football=== [[Italy national football team|Italy]] used the stadium as their base for training camp during the [[Football World Cup 2002|2002 World Cup]], and cast images of the team members footprints are on display outside the stadium. The '''Sendai Cup''' (An international youth football tournament) has been held annually since 2003. Italy, France [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]], and [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]] have participated, along with the hosts, [[Japan national football team|Japan]]. Exhibition matches between Vegalta Sendai and [[A.C. ChievoVerona]] and [[S.S. Lazio]] have been played at Sendai Stadium as well. The match with Chievo in 2003 was the final club game for [[Oliver Bierhoff]].{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/news/2003/june/4/japan-stars-tune-up-for-internationals/?print=yes|title=Japan stars tune up for internationals|publisher=Soccerway|date=2004-06-03|accessdate=2008-04-08}} ===Rugby=== On June 16, 2007, the stadium was the venue for [[Japan national rugby union team|Japan]] vs. [[Samoa national rugby union team|Samoa]] in the [[2007 IRB Pacific Nations Cup]]. It was the first time an international rugby game had been played in the [[Tōhoku region]]. On June 15, 2008, Japan defeated [[Tonga national rugby union team|Tonga]] 35-13 at the stadium in the [[2008 IRB Pacific Nations Cup]]. ==Access== * [[Nanboku Line (Sendai)|Nanboku Line]]: 8 minutes walk from [[Izumi-Chūō Station (Miyagi)|Izumi-Chūō Station]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050308185853/http://www.wldcup.com/Asia/stadia/sendai.html Pictures of Sendai Stadium] (Much information on this site is out of date) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070716124228/http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/asia/japan/tohoku/sendai_stadium.shtml WorldStadiums.com entry] {{Vegalta Sendai}} {{J. League venues}} {{Pine Bowl navbox}} {{Collegiate American Football in Japan navbox}} [[Category:Sports venues in Sendai]] [[Category:Football venues in Japan]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in Japan]] [[Category:Vegalta Sendai]] [[Category:American football venues in Japan]] [[Category:1997 establishments in Japan]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1997]] {{japan-stadium-stub}}
